speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is my duty to table five petitions today. These petitioners ask Parliament to convince or put pressure on the government to reinstate the Court Challenges Program. As we know, the government abolished this program in the last budget.
These petitioners maintain that this Court Challenges Program was and must continue to be an essential tool in developing constitutional rights and must continue to give all Canadians equal access to the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
They ask Parliament to reconsider the possibility of restoring the Court Challenges Program, which gives all Canadians equal access.

Mr. Speaker, I have three petitions today.
In the first, petitioners ask Parliament to ensure the CRTC regulate the use of foul language on radio and television. They believe the current usage of the amount of foul language that is used counteracts parental efforts in the home and it undermines what it is they are trying to do. They indicate that foul language is unacceptable
on radio, television, or in other media whether it is used in English or in French.

My second petition is from petitioners who point out that Canada's greatest challenges are in the area of the social sciences. They refer to violence, abuse, environment, aboriginal issues, poverty especially among children, illiteracy, et cetera.
They point out as well the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council's providing of the kind of leadership that permitted individuals to address those issues.
They point out as well that it has now been merged with the Canada Council. They indicate there was no consultation. They ask that this decision be deferred, that there be consultation, and subsequent to that a decision be made.

In my final petition, the petitioners point out there needs to be substantial investments in education if we are to compete internationally, that we respond to globalization if we are to increase productivity. They indicate there is still the 3 per cent tax on student loans.
They point out there has been an additional six months of interest added to student loans. They indicate as well the goods and services tax still exists on books, tuition fees are increasing, student debt is increasing at an alarming rate and they indicate there have been major cuts to transfer payments to the provinces.
They ask the government to review its policies with respect to education and retraining.

Mr. Speaker, I have the pleasure of presenting quite an impressive petition signed by some 300 constituents, collected by Mrs. Edith Iwama of my riding of York West, pertaining to the issue of illegal drug abuse which is unfortunately afflicting many of our youth right across the country, including metropolitan Toronto.

Routine Proceedings
The petitioners are calling upon the government, the minister, in particular the Solicitor General, to amend our Narcotics Control Act so the proceeds from drug seizures, rather than going completely and solely into the Government of Canada general revenue fund be shared with both police forces and local organizations which are responsible on the leading edge, on the streets, and in the back alleyways of trying to put back this drug epidemic.
I might add that many of the people who signed this petition are police officers.

Mr. Speaker, I have the honour to present a petition to the House signed by over 125 constituents from Victoria and the surrounding area. They are concerned with the provisions of section 462.2 of the Criminal Code dealing with literature for "illicit drug use", and in particular the application by the administration of justice of that section respecting the uses of hemp and literature in respect of the uses of hemp, which the petitioners say has many beneficial uses.
The petitioners call on Parliament to amend or remove from the Criminal Code section 462.2 so that the freedom of Canadians is there to discuss and consider the possible beneficial uses of hemp or other substances.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to address the questions which are before this House in Bill C-55.
The petitioners state that many women in Canada are living in poverty after years of home making which allowed their husbands to pursue careers without the burden of child bearing, child rearing and housework. Many of these women are disentitled by divorce to an equal share of their husband's federal pension credits accumulated during their marriage.
The government has stated in the past that it is in favour of mandatory automatic pension credit splitting. The pensioners request that Parliament amend Bill C-55 which is before this House so that all federal superannuation acts in which inequities exist
allow for the retroactive pension credit splitting for all divorced spouses so that they may receive half of the federal pension credits accumulated by both spouses during the period of their marriage.

I have a second petition which addresses the fate of refugee claimants in Canada, which is deplorable. They state that Canada, until recently, had an enviable record of compassion for the underprivileged, especially refugees, and that Canadian taxpayers have spent in the past three years an unjustifiably exorbitant amount of funds on a determination system that has proved to be inequitable and ineffective.
They call on Parliament for an administrative-review, which this party has also repeatedly called for, which grants a general amnesty to all refugee claimants presently in Canada subject to the exclusion only of those who have serious criminal records in Canada or abroad for offences that would be considered serious in Canada.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise under Standing Order 36 to table a petition signed by residents of northern British Columbia, and in particular the city of Prince George.
These people are still concerned about this government's bringing in of the goods and services tax and they call on Parliament to reform the taxation system so that there is an effective minimum tax on wealthy individuals and corporations.

Mr. Speaker, I have a petition from the residents of the Township of Front of Yonge in Leeds County petitioning the CRTC to prevent the erection of a radio-TV tower in their community because of the negative effects that they perceive the installation of this tower would have in that particular location.

Mr. Speaker, I have a petition, certified correct by the clerk as to form and content, signed by residents of my riding wherein the petitioners sheweth that Canada has put forward proposals for amending the Constitution of Canada. The government has established a citizens' forum to ascertain the views of Canadians on numerous matters and committees to consult with the people of Canada concerning the proposals. The Supreme Court upheld that the Constitution of Canada belongs to the people.
The petitioners call upon Parliament to enact legislation providing for a referendum of the people binding upon Parliament to accept or reject constitutional amendments proposed by the government.

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons) moved
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
that Bill C-81, an act to provide for referendums on the Constitution of Canada, be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be speaking in favour of this bill today so that we get this important legislation moving.
It is important that Canadians be acquainted with the proposed legislation and are informed about how it relates to the constitutional issue. This legislation is a precautionary measure. It is no more and no less than that. This legislation would enable the federal government to hold a referendum on Canada's constitutional future should such a step be required.
Under current law, the federal government could not hold a referendum now even if it wanted to. There is no law to allow it. The bill would correct this obvious limitation.
In a democratic society, particularly one undergoing constitutional change, the idea of the federal government having this ability only makes common sense. It is simply a matter of management prudence.
If there were no legislation in place permitting a referendum, the people of Canada would rightly condemn Parliament for not having this instrument at hand to use in dealing with any eventuality.
In saying that this measure is a precautionary one, it is important to underline that there is nothing in the legislation saying that there will be a referendum at all. No decision to hold a federal referendum has been made. Likewise, the bill does not say anything about when a federal referendum might be held. Neither is there any provision in the legislation, nor has there been any decision about what a referendum question would ask.

Agreed.

May 19, 1992
Government Orders
There is no provision in the legislation saying what a so-called victory would be. Speculation on anyone's part on any of these issues is meaningless because the bill before us only provides that a referendum could be held-could be held, nothing more.
Probably there are some people who do not want the federal government even to have the power to hold a referendum and who will oppose the bill for this reason alone. They are entitled to their views, but it is our view as a government that it would be irresponsible to leave Canada without all appropriate and democratic means necessary to advance the constitutional reform process.
This government believes that Canada has the right to hold a referendum if it wants to, just as the provinces have a perfect right to hold referenda on matters of their choice. There is simply no sensible argument in favour of the position that the provinces should be able to hold referenda but the federal government should not.
No one on the government side has claimed-I certainly do not-that this legislation is perfect in all respects. I look forward to any practical suggestions to improve it, but I do believe that under our Constitution this bill meets the test of fairness that reasonable Canadians demand.
In drafting the bill, the government kept the principle of fairness very much in mind. We wanted to ensure that any referendum held under the provisions of this bill would be fair and workable, and would be seen as such by the Canadian people.
In addressing the issue of fairness, a key feature of this bill is that the wording of any referendum would have to be approved by Parliament. Without Parliament's approval of the question, no referendum could be held at all.
Second, the Canada Elections Act legislation which enjoys the great respect and confidence of Canadians throughout this country would provide the basic framework under which any referendum would be held. The Chief Electoral Officer would have the same responsibility for the conduct of a referendum as he has for the conduct of a general election. He would be responsible for making the regulations under the Referendum Act to adapt the Canada Elections Act process to a referendum just as he has the responsibility for making the regulations to adapt the Canada Elections Act to a general election.
Third, the bill assures that the process is open and transparent. Anyone or any group intending to spend more than $5,000 in any federal referendum campaign must register. Any contribution over $250 and the name of the contributor must be identified.
Fourth, free broadcast time will be allocated equally to both sides by the broadcast arbitrator, which is a position under the Canada Elections Act, by using criteria set out in this legislation.
The bill requires networks to provide at least 90 minutes of free broadcast time to each side of the referendum question.
Fifth, any point of view on the referendum may be advanced via normal advertising, a matter to be decided between participants and broadcasters, subject to the governing CRTC regulations which require broadcasters to allocate all broadcast time during a referendum campaign on an equitable basis.
Some are of the opinion that there should be further restrictions in the legislation. For example, some might argue it should require that strict limits be put on spending. We examined this question very carefully. From the government's point of view, strict controls on spending would be helpful. As a practical matter, however, we believe that they would be ineffective and do little to ensure fairness.
In fact it could be counterproductive to have a referendum process which does not engender confidence and trust in the people.
The reason we hold this opinion is that while spending limits per se may not be contrary to the charter, there is the practical issue of making these limits meaningful.
The only way to ensure these limits would be honoured is to force everyone to campaign via yes or no committees. The courts would very possibly view this as an infringement upon people's freedom of association and freedom of speech. The practical effect of a successful court challenge would be to disrupt and discredit a referendum campaign, hardly a palatable result for Canadians.
Some may ask why is it then that the parties can be restricted in their spending during election campaigns. Hon. members should bear in mind that while the elections act may limit the spending of candidates and political parties in a federal election, it does not limit the
May 19, 1992

spending of others during election campaigns as a result of a successful court challenge in 1984.
These others are individuals and groups with various options about current issues and who advance these opinions during an election campaign. The courts have ruled that they have a perfect right to express their views.
Some may suggest that even if restricting participation to yes or no committees is impossible, the bill should set spending limits on any individual or group. This could be done. But it would not be meaningful because people would simply set up one committee after another in order to accommodate any amount of spending they wished to undertake. When one committee has exhausted its limit, another group made up of essentially the same people or groups could be set up and spend up to the limit and so on. The net result would be that the limit would not be enforceable in any practical way.
In addition, people would develop a disrespect for the referendum process as a result of the loophole preventing any limitation on the number of committees.
So having no limitation gives them respect.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
The hon. member for Hamilton East is again heckling from her seat. I would like to acquaint the hon. member for Hamilton East with the document Canada Referendum Bill, An Explanation by the Minister of State for Federal-Provincial Relations 1978. The minister of state at that time was the Hon. Marc Lalonde. This following statement was made in that document:
"No country has ever conducted a referendum in which total expenditures by parties or groups were controlled. The government is convinced that any attempt in this direction must involve unacceptable infringements of freedom of association and speech. Limits on the size of contributions or expenditures may be made by individual persons who preserve all democratic rights while ensuring that no contributor will have an unfair advantage because of its withdrawal".
This document is available in the Library. It also examines how different countries handle referenda. For
Government Orders
example, Australia has no ceilings on expenditures by parties in referendum campaigns, in contrast with strict limits on candidates during election campaigns.
California has referenda with no limits on spending campaigns.
France has referenda. There are no limits on spending by parties or other groups during referendum campaigns.
Ireland has no limits on expenses during referenda.
Italy does not impose a ceiling on campaign expenditures and the state bears the administration costs.
In Massachusetts, there are no limits on spending.
Norway has set no limitations on expenditures by umbrella movements or political parties.
In Switzerland there are no limitations on expenditures by political parties, individuals or associations during referendum or election campaigns.
In the United Kingdom, there were no limits on the expenditures of the organizations that campaigned for the Common Market referendum even though it has very strict limitations on candidates during elections.
The previous Liberal government reached the conclusion that the only way to impose limits was by having people forced to campaign within fixed groups and it was an infringement on their freedom of association, their freedom of speech. Even in common law countries like the United Kingdom, this was felt unsustainable and that is why they have no limitations.
That is where the government came to it. I do not quite understand the heckling from the other side because we are talking here about a practical detail. This is not a philosophical question. I wish the hon. member for Hamilton East would appreciate that what is at stake here is not partisan advantage. What is at stake here is the future of the country.
Lest there be any question as to whether it would be challenged, I have a letter from the National Citizens Coalition which-

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
There are other legal opinions which will be available. I am sure the hon. member is not as interested in that as she is in anything else having to do with the future of this countiy.
Enacting laws which are simply impossible to enforce and as a result promote public disrespect for the law is poor law-making indeed. Canadians have the right to expect more from their federal Parliament.
Others might take the position that Quebec's referendum law should be used as a basis for any federal referendum. Quebec's referendum law deals with its own political culture in a way that its own National Assembly believes appropriate. Laws to fit all of Canada must reflect the reality of the entire country and not just part of it.
I would like to turn to the issue of government spending for a moment. I have heard that many who think they are promoting fairness believe that the bill should be changed to prevent or limit in some way the federal government from participating in any referendum campaign.
First, let me underline that no decision to hold a referendum has been made so any thought about the federal government's role is highly speculative.
If there is a campaign, no law should limit federal activity without a concurrent limitation on provincial government activity. Otherwise it would be unfair to the federal government if the provinces could spend anything they want and the federal government could not. A federal law limiting provincial spending in this way would be anathema to the whole concept of responsible government. One could just imagine Bob Rae or Don Getty or Clyde Wells or any other premier meekly submitting to a federal law telling them what they could and could not do with provincial moneys approved by their own legislatures. The very thought of such an intervention into the provincial spending power is abhorrent.
Furthermore any limitation on the federal government's role in any referendum campaign would have to include all federal spending. That would include spending by members of Parliament.
I can imagine the howls of protest and questions of privilege if the travel, householders, telephone use and other expenses of MPs were restricted if they were directed in support of one side or another of a referendum question.
Under this scenario, Parliament would be hamstrung to the point at which responsible government itself would be put at risk; a fine message indeed to Canadians in the midst of a referendum on the future of their country.
Canadians recognize that the pursuit of perfection must not become the enemy of progress. We have all seen the difficult process of constitutional reform over the past two years. The government has ensured that Canadians have had the opportunity to express their views and comment, debate and otherwise express their thoughts on how to make a better Canada.
From the citizens' forum to the constitutional conferences to the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee, Canadians know a great deal about what is necessary to keep Canada constitutionally fit for the next century. However, one thing that will not serve Canada well is blind insistence on perfection at the expense of getting this job done well and fairly. This bill is no different.
A perfect bill is beyond the power of anyone in this Parliament to craft, much less implement. We must, however, ensure workability and fairness. To the extent
May 19, 1992

that it is possible, I believe this bill accomplishes this purpose.
I recognize that in an adversarial system as we have, it is common practice for ridicule, harassment, barracking and so on to occur. Perhaps that plays somewhat of a role in ensuring that issues are examined and that it helps the public get some sense if both sides were argued vigorously-
The laughter from the member for Kingston and the Islands is a disappointment because I would have thought that he would recognize that what we are talking about here is enabling legislation and technical details to allow for the possible use of a tool which might help to keep this country together. If that is a subject of mirth, then I say again how disappointed I am in the hon. member that he should find this a subject of mirth.
This is an attempt to come up with enabling legislation for referenda. I have given the arguments as honestly, openly and fairly as I can. I have indicated in my remarks and I have indicated previously and privately that the question of spending limits would be helpful to the government.
The practicality is that it would be an infringement on the freedom of association and freedom of speech. As I have indicated, every country in the world that has referenda has reached the same conclusion. We have legal opinions to that regard and I would ask the hon. members opposite to seriously consider the consequences of putting something into the bill that would be challenged. We know it would be challenged and possibly it could be successfully challenged. I ask them to think about the circumstances in which it became advisable and desirable to keep this country united, to have a referendum. In the midst of it, a court has declared the process null and void because of the infringement. If they were on this side of the House, would they be taking the same risk?
I do not think, if they look at it carefully and think about what is at stake, they would be doing that. As I say, some of the antics in the House are part of our adversarial system and I understand that but please, please, please recognize what is at stake here. Recognize that this is a sincere effort to bring forward as fair a piece of legislation as possible. Act in that responsible manner

and we will be doing the citizens who support us and the country a service for what we have been doing.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we in the official opposition support the concept of this bill but we do not believe that it is anywhere near perfect.
We believe that there are many important improvements which are needed and we believe that it is a step in the right direction. It is not a step as big as we would like.
It is not as bold a step as we would like, but it is a step in the direction of giving the Canadian people the ultimate voice in determining the structure of their government.
We were pleased a year ago when the Speech from the Throne opening the present session of Parliament indicated that legislation regarding constitutional referenda would be forthcoming. It is disappointing, however, that this legislation took more than a year to emerge from the government's legislative mill. It is disappointing because any bill of this nature demands thorough consideration. It requires public airing. It requires the advice of experts. It requires careful thought by members of Parliament, who must pass judgment on it.
The delay of a year gives Parliament less time to do this job. This delay means that we must undertake a task demanding great precision within a time frame that is unnecessarily short. We have used every possible forum in the last few years, especially since April 1991, to express our support for a national referendum as a device for legitimizing constitutional change.
It is our belief that a revised Constitution should require popular approval, not only with a national majority, but also with a majority within each of the regions of this country.
We put this position forward successfully to the Beau-doin-Edwards committee on the constitutional amendments and we did the same with the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee. It is difficult for us to understand why a government that included this proposal in its Speech from the Throne and whose own supporters twice endorsed the suggestion in important special joint committees has only brought forward its legislation at the

May 19, 1992
Government Orders
last minute, forcing Parliament to work, as it were, under the gun.
Some of the issues that we wish to address and some of the suggestions that we have for change to the bill are matters that would be more adequately considered in the fullness of time. Some of our differences with the government on the form of this bill depend upon the interpretations of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. The government has attained legal opinions on some of these issues, but we believe that Parliament should have the opportunity to consider legal opinions from a variety of sources before being called upon to decide.
I hope that the government House leader will undertake to live up to his commitment of some days ago to provide this House and all members of Parliament with copies of those legal opinions which he has now sought.
We have a number of strongly held views on the form of the legislation to which the government replies there are constitutional barriers. We believe that Parliament, given the time it needs, can reconcile these views with the charter.
I cannot help but observe that, given the time that has been lost by the government's internal agonizing, the public might have better been served had the government many months ago asked a parliamentary committee to prepare this legislation. Two such committees had no difficulty in agreeing on the principle of a constitutional referendum. Surely another would have been able to tap into the considerable expertise, both in Canada and abroad, in order to produce a more acceptable bill in a more timely fashion.
We were given some advance briefing by the government. We take note of the government's profession of openness in entertaining our suggestions for conducting and improving the bill. I do not intend to show any meanness of spirit when I say, as I am compelled to say, that we hope the government's proclaimed intention to proceed in a consultative manner will be more reflective of the generally understood meaning of the word "consult" than demonstrated last week by the government House leader.
Consultations consist of more than informing and more than rejection out of hand. The government House leader should be careful about attributing perfection to the same advisers to whom, when he was on this side of the House, he attributed the precise opposite. He may
have made some compromises with his colleagues in order to squeeze this bill out of the government's legislative bottomless pit, but if we really want an acceptable law to emerge out of the legislative process, he is going to have to accept broader based judgments than those he has had up to the present time.
On April 21 the Leader of the Official Opposition issued a nine-point constitutional plan and one of these points was that the final word on the constitutional framework of the Canadian government should belong to the people of Canada.
His view and the view of the Liberal Party of Canada is that a national referendum on constitutional change should require the approval of the majority of the voters nationally as well as of the majority of the voters in each of the regions of this country.
Thus, a new constitutional arrangement would enjoy the support of the majority of Canadians while no one region of this nation would ever be made to feel that the other regions had forced it to accept an arrangement with which it was not comfortable.
The Liberal Party of Canada believes that the day is long gone when the Canadian people will accept a constitution that is brokered behind closed doors. We do not accept the self-serving separatist argument that Quebec was left out of the 1980-1982 constitutional agreement.
Not only did the majority of elected representatives in Parliament from that province support that arrangement, but successive provincial governments in the province of Quebec have quite happily made use of the new constitutional provisions that resulted from the 1982 agreement.
Nonetheless, the absence of the clearly expressed opinion of the people on the 1982 agreement serves to perpetrate that vicious myth. Had the 1982 arrangement been put to the people, had the voters responded with a national majority and a majority in each of the regions, I am certain had they done so the entire nation would have been spared a decade of bitter, bitter misrepresentations.
In the event that arrangement had been rejected either nationally or by one of more of the regions, while we would have had to go back to the drawing boards, the nation would at least have been spared these misunderstandings and these intolerable misrepresentations.

I do not understand why there is resistance to giving the people the final authority in determining the structure of their government. Constitutional amendment by referendum has been a normal feature of innumerable democratic nations for centuries. The Swiss have used this device for centuries and France enjoys its most stable structure of government since Napoleon under a constitution that is subject to comparatively frequent amending referenda. Even Britain, the citadel, if you will, of parliamentary democracy, resorted to a referendum concerning its major constitutional change in joining the European Community.
Canadians are well known for their generosity and tolerance. They are an intelligent and educated people and they usually demonstrate a remarkable sophistication in their political behaviour. The Canadian population of 1992 is as well prepared as a whole as any group of officials, elected or not, to make the decisions on the basic structure of its government. It is unreasonable and unconscionable to suggest otherwise.
If democracy itself lends support to the concept of constitutional amendment through a referendum, human nature provides a clinching argument. A national referendum is the only device whereby all Canadians in all regions are able to give an answer to the same question or questions. This provides them with the chance to say yes to Canada and, more important, it gives Canadians a chance to say to yes to each other.
It is for these reasons that we are unhappy with the fact that this bill would leave the matter of a referendum as merely an option. The bill does not even require that any referendum be held in all of the provinces. It provides that the vote need only be held in one or more provinces.
In our view this is an unfortunate provision. It leaves the purpose of the bill open to misinterpretation. Given the particular timing of the introduction of the bill and the strange provision about one or more provinces, there may be cynics who suspect that the government's intention is to use a referendum, not as an instrument of
Government Orders
legitimizing a constitution, but as a tool to be used against a provincial premier or premiers.
This would be unacceptable and unfortunate. It represents a denial of the ultimate sovereignty of the people and it demonstrates a contempt for the political integrity of the duly elected governments of the provinces.
If a referendum is to be held, it must be held only for positive and constructive constitutional purposes. It should not be regarded as the course of a last resort. It must be viewed as the natural and legitimate democratic path. Canadians will not tolerate an exercise of whipping up passions, costing upward of $100 million, for the sole purposes of partisan, political one-upmanship.
We do not believe that a referendum should be optional. In order to be credible it ought to be mandatory. We disagree with the three-year sunset provision of the bill. We believe that the referendum should be a permanent part of the process for revising the Canadian Constitution. Nor can it be restricted to one or just a few provinces. The referendum ought to be national so that all Canadians in all regions of this country have the opportunity to speak on the same issue.
The referendum must also provide for majorities in each of the regions. Never again can we afford to let partisans in any one region create a malicious myth that they have been ganged up on by all of the others.
We are also concerned about the method provided in the bill for the framing of the question or questions to be asked in the referendum itself.
The bill provides that the government will frame that question or questions and place it before Parliament for three days of debate in each House where presumably amendments may be offered by the other parties.
There are two difficulties here. First, the rules of Parliament severely restrict the scope for offering and considering amendments. Second, the period allocated for debate is so short that under the rules at most one-quarter of the members of this House could participate on so important a question affecting our country.

May 19, 1992
Government Orders
Under these rules a government could draw up a loaded question and ram it through the House under conditions similar to the most abusive use of closure. Let it be said that the gang across the way has demonstrated time and time again its receptiveness in order to utilize closure at every opportunity.
In our opinion the bill should establish a formal process of inter-party consultations, and I underline inter-party consultations, real consultations with give and take for the formulation of the question. Only under this kind of arrangement can so abbreviated a period of debate be tolerated by members on this side of the House.
There is no reason that a system of inter-party consultations should not be included in the bill. The history of amending the Canadian Constitution is one of remarkable consensus between parties in the House of Commons. There has rarely in our history been partisan division remaining at the point of ultimate decision by the House of Commons. This was true in 1981-82 and 1987-88 and on the most previous occasions. This legislation should recognize explicitly our traditional consensus approach to such important matters.
We in the Liberal Party are also concerned about the absence of acceptable financial controls on the referendum campaign itself. The provisions in the bill for any person or group spending more than $5,000 to register and to account for donations and expenditure constitute in our view no control at all. It remains open for either side of the question to spend huge amounts without limitation.
If the results of the referendum are to be considered credible-and this is key-it is essential that the process be transparently fair. We must never allow the losing side to be in a position to claim that victory was bought. There must never be permitted a system that is loaded on the side of the rich and the powerful. This means that over-all expenditure on each side of the campaign must have some form of limitation.
The government House leader asserts that such a system would require so-called umbrella committees which, according to the legal opinions which he has received but which we have not, would conflict with the
freedom of political expression guaranteed by the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
As a lawyer I should like to see legal opinions on this issue obtained from several sources, and as a legislator I should like to have the opportunity to see how the law could be formulated to effect spending restrictions within the ambit of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
Any referendum must not only be fair; it must be seen to be fair in all regions of this country. Even a shadow of suspicion will destroy the value of that referendum. In our attempt to build a strong national fabric we cannot risk giving ammunition to those who would destroy that.
We have in Canada a long and unsavoury history of untoward financial dealings during election campaigns. We cannot take pride in 125 years of overspending, going even further back than the Pacific scandal of 1873 and coming up as recently as the massive third party interventions in the federal election of 1988. This has been well documented by researchers, by experts, and by those of us who follow the political scheme in this country.
The Lortie commission made a number of recommendations that are now before a special committee of this House which will, one hopes, recommend corrective and needed actions. new idea of appointing two witnesses representing the two sides, whether we have umbrellas here or not.
I do not think we were given a very clear explanation. Of course, this is only a preliminary debate.

Mr. Speaker, my distinguished colleague raised three points.
First, on the double majority issue, I can inform the hon. member that personally, I would be in favour of a double majority in a referendum if the results were legally binding. In this particular case, under this legislation, the referendum will certainly have moral weight but is not binding and does not amend the Constitution.
Some people say the present formula is a good one, while others are less enthusiastic, but as far as I know, it will be 7/50 or unanimity, for the time being.
Since this referendum is not binding, I personally see no need for a double majority, but I do understand what the hon. member is trying to say.
As far as the Canada Elections Act is concerned, I know a committee of this House is considering the legislation, and I am sure that with the hon. member for Saint-Denis as a member of the team, the committee will do an excellent job.
The hon. member realizes of course, that this type of amendment which mainly concerns the Canada Elections Act should be the result of a consensus among commitee members. I am certainly looking forward to his suggestions. In that, I hope the hon. member, and members of the other parties as well, will make a number of suggestions that we will be able to adopt by the end of June, so these improvements will be in place for the next election campaign.
As for the issue of the witnesses, or representatives at the polling stations on election day, the purpose of the bill is to have the yes and no sides each have one representative at the ballot box. I assume this is what will happen: The returning officer for the electoral district of Vercheres -I am taking my own riding as an example -will probably ask the "federalist" forces to appoint or suggest representatives who will be appointed by the returning officer. I assume the returning officer will also

May 19, 1992
Government Orders
ask my friends in the Bloc quebecois or other opposing factions for a list of witnesses or representatives at the 241 polling stations in my riding, to ensure there are no doubts about the ballot counts.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Any more questions or comments?

Mr. Speaker, there is a major contradiction in what the minister said, which I found very surprising. He tells us the referendum results will have no legal value, will not be legally binding on anyone, but he said at the beginning of his speech that he wants a referendum and I quote: "to settle the constitutional debate once and for all".
Either the referendum settles something or it does not. I wish the minister would tell us why, as a Quebecer, he thinks a referendum that ignores the entire amending formula could possibly settle the constitutional debate once and for all.

Mr. Speaker, the whole point of this referendum legislation, and especially the current process headed by Mr. Clark, is that the federal government will try and settle the constitutional question once and for all.
The hon. member knows perfectly well that all the energy being spent on the constitutional question would be better spent on economic issues and on finding jobs for Quebecers and Canadians.
I think the time has come to terminate the process. If we think a referendum should be held, we will do it, but it is not a binding referendum. However, we see it as a device that could bring the whole constitutional process to a conclusion.
This is only one phase. We have gone through several phases, as I mentioned in my speech. However, it is one phase we would prefer to avoid. If this week in Montreal or next week in Toronto, Mr. Clark's group were to reach an agreement, it would be a relief. Quebec would be able to hold its referendum, and everything would be fine.
However, if there is no agreement, I think it only makes sense for the government to consider all the options. I think it stands to reason that a democratic country like Canada should go to the people.

Very briefly, Mr. Speaker, the bill contains no provisions for spending limits. Many of us feel spending limits should be set. The Liberal Party and others suggested a reference to the Supreme Court to find out whether the bill violates the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
Is the government, through its minister, prepared to tell the House today that it is willing to refer this bill immediately to the Supreme Court for an opinion on the implications of the bill for the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms?

Mr. Speaker, personally, I would prefer to see spending limits in this kind of bill. However, officials of the federal Department of Justice were unanimous in their opinion that if people were forced to associate under the aegis of two umbrella-committees-which would be the only way to limit spending, because one could then limit the spending of these committeess-and if this were challenged before the courts, the group or person initiating the challenge would have an excellent chance of winning their case. If this were to happen during a referendum period, we have no way of knowing what the courts would do. The court might decide that the clause in question was ultra vires or it might decide that the bill itself was ultra vires, which could have disastrous consequences.
To answer the questions raised by the hon. member for Ottawa-Vanier and the hon. member for Saint-Denis, at the committee stage we intend to call as witnesses the people who gave us these legal opinions. At that stage, either my colleagues will be convinced, or if members of the two opposition parties have a better idea that would make it possible to get around this legal point, then, as the government House leader said, we are prepared to improve the bill in order to obtain the broadest possible consensus among members of this House.
May 19, 1992

Mr. Speaker, we in the Liberal Party support the principle of this bill, that is, we support the principle that the new constitutional proposals should be submitted to a national referendum or a plebiscite for the approval or disapproval of the Canadian people.
But we have serious reservations about several parts or clauses in the bill. In particular, we are opposed to the bill in so far as it does not place serious financial controls on the different groups that will participate in the referendum campaign. Because it does not do that, we do not think that the process can or will be fair. Second, we oppose the bill in so far as it does not provide for a majority in all the regions of the country. The bill simply sets that aside and provides for a simple majority right across the country.
We believe if you are going to have a national referendum or a plebiscite on constitutional proposals, it must be perceived as being absolutely fair. Otherwise, once you have the results in, it will not have the validity or will not solve the problems that you wish to solve. You submit these proposals to a referendum because you want to gain the consensus or the approval of the Canadian people on a new constitutional proposal. But if, for one minute, regions of the country perceive the referendum process as not being fair, or if they perceive it as having been bought off by big financial interests, then you will not have the results you want, and no matter who wins or who loses the other side is going to claim that the result is tainted because it has been manoeuvred or manipulated by financial interests or because one region of the country with a greater population will simply overwhelm another region of the country and impose its views on that region.
We in the Liberal Party approve of a referendum in principle because as far back as April of 1991, the Leader of the Opposition, proposed, with eight other points, that there be a referendum to approve of the new constitutional proposals. His reason, supported by our party, is that the Constitution, different from other laws, is the basic law of the land, and the basic law of the land is the law by which we give authority to the Parliament of Canada, by which we give authority to the provincial governments and the federal government.
The people are saying that they agree with this process, this law, by which certain powers are given to
Government Orders
members of Parliament, by which certain powers are given to the Government of Canada, by which certain powers are given to provincial governments and legislative assemblies.
If we are going to change that basic law, it is appropriate that the people of Canada be involved in approving or disapproving that basic law that we call our Constitution.
I mentioned our two serious reservations with respect to the bill before us; first, that it does not provide adequately for the financial control of the parties taking part in the referendum and second, it does not provide for a double majority.
Let me explain the double majority. In any referendum on constitutional proposals there should not only be a majority for those proposals from all the voters, right across the country, but there must also be a majority in the four or five regions of the country. There should be a majority in Atlantic Canada, a majority in Quebec, a majority in Ontario and a majority in the west and the north. In this way, we get around the difficulty of what happened in the only other two referendums or plebiscites that we have had in Canadian history; where in Quebec they voted one way and in the rest of the country they voted another way. It only led to more disunity or division.
Let me refer to a bit of history. As I pointed out, we have had only two so-called referendums in Canada. I think I should clarify that as well. Usually the word "referendum" is understood to mean a binding consultation with people, such as proposition 13 in California. The people are consulted, they vote on a law or on a proposition. Once they have voted, the assembly or the Parliament has no say whatsoever, the results are binding. That is the strict definition of a referendum.
What we have had in Canada on many occasions, both federally and provincially, are plebiscites, which have a serious political impact but are not binding. We have had two at the national level. The first one in 1878 was a referendum on whether or not we should allow liquor to be sold. It was a referendum on whether we should have prohibition as they had in the United States or whether it should be left to local option. The proposal carried in all other provinces of Canada but was defeated in Quebec. Even then Quebec was distinct and believed in a more flexible approach to the sale of liquor than they did in the other provinces.

Government Orders
The other instance at the national level was in April of 1942 on the subject of conscription, of forcibly requiring Canadians of a certain age to serve in the armed forces in the Second World War. It came about because in the national election of 1940, which Mackenzie King and the Liberals won, Mr. King had promised there would be no conscription for overseas service. However, when we got more into the war and things were not going good for us-good for us or good for the allies-Mr. King sought a way to be released from his election promise of 1940 and passed the Dominion Plebiscite Act of 1942. The plebiscite took place and the yes side won a vote in favour of conscription. But once again in Quebec, 72 per cent of the population voted against conscription. If we want unity after any referendum then we should learn the lessons of that referendum.
The no forces in Quebec and across the country were not even allowed access to the public broadcasting system to explain their point of view. In other words, in 1942 those in Quebec on that referendum were not even allowed to appear on Radio Canada or CBC Radio to explain their point of view and why they were opposed to conscription. The whole process was viewed as being unfair.
At this point I am not taking sides on the question. What I am trying to do is to demonstrate to the House, to the government and to the Canadian population that if we have another referendum it has to be perceived by the Canadian people as being absolutely fair.
It will not be absolutely fair if both sides to the question have not had ample opportunity to present their points of view and their arguments, or if it is also perceived that by massive advertising, which costs millions and millions of dollars, one side is able to out-spend the other side and therefore win the question.
We know that in the election of 1988, the last election, many of us in the opposition parties, the Liberal Party, the New Democratic Party and other elements in Canada, believed that election was won by third party groups who supported the free trade question and were not subject to spending limits.
The Lortie commission studied election spending and how to control spending by large corporations on elections. It said that there must be more control so that third party interests will not be able to influence elections simply by the size of their financial expenditures on advertising, whether on television or in newspapers and magazines, and so on.
If we are going to have a referendum and it is going to be perceived by all parties to be fair, then there must be controls on the amounts of money spent on either side. There must be adequate opportunity for both sides of the question to properly express their views and to give their arguments.
Also, in order to come out of the referendum with people accepting the result and having national unity no matter what the result, and if not unity at least an understanding between peoples, then there must be majorities in the different regions of Canada and not simply a national majority as we had in 1942 and in 1878. If we do not do that then we are going to end up with a split country.
I have listened to the ministers argue that we do not really have to do that this time because in fact this is a plebiscite and it is not binding. If it is not binding, then we do not have to provide for regional majorities. The minister and the government are speaking from a very legalistic point of view.
I took part in the plebiscite in Quebec in 1980 and it was not legally binding either. It was an advisory sort of opinion, but once you are into it, it is a very serious matter. People do spend money. They spend a lot of time and dedicate their lives to winning one side or the other of the referendum.
To not clearly set out in advance how the results are going to be treated will lead to a lot of confusion and a lot of ill feelings. We do not want that. It is much better to say in advance, right in the law, that in order for the proposals to win, what is needed will be not only a national majority but also majorities in the different regions of the country. People will then know what the rules of the game are. Of course, they know that the results are not binding, but they know that the political influence of the results are overwhelming.
May 19, 1992

It would be very difficult for a premier of a province or for the Prime Minister of Canada to deny the results of the referendum or to try to do something differently when the people of his province or the people of the country have spoken clearly in the referendum.
The political impact will be very significant even though the results are not binding. Consequently, if the political impact is going to be significant, then the rules of the game have to be spelled out.
The rules of the game, if we are going to come out better after the referendum than when we went into it, should make it clear that it will have to be a double majority with a majority nationally and a majority in the regions of the country.
The government House leader has said that one reason for not putting financial spending limits in the bill is that these would be subject to challenge based on the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
He refers to freedom of opinion. Our charter guarantees freedom of opinion and he feels that if we try and put restrictions on the expression of opinion through spending limits, on what can be spent on advertising, that that would be against the charter of rights.
But it also says in the charter that these rights are subject to reasonable limits prescribed by law as can be demonstrated and justified in a free and democratic society.
I think that putting such financial limits in the bill can be justified in a free and democratic society because they guarantee the democratic society. To have no spending limits, no financial controls, then those with the most money control the results. That is not democracy.
When the minister says that, we would be interested in seeing the legal opinions, more than one legal opinion. We would like to see the legal opinions he has from the Department of Justice as well as some independent legal opinions on this point.
As a lawyer, I am convinced that there could be and we could formulate much better financial controls and spending limits in this bill that would be acceptable under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
I referred to our experience at the national level with plebiscites in Canada. I pointed out that we only had two other examples in our history: the prohibition of liquor situation in 1878, and conscription in 1942.
Government Orders
Canadians should know that referenda and plebiscites have been used much more often at the provincial level. It is interesting that they have been used more often in the west than in the east. As a matter of fact, the more you go toward the east the less they are used.
For example, in British Columbia we have had nine referenda, with the last one in 1972. Alberta has had seven, with the last one in 1971. In Saskatchewan and Manitoba they have had six referenda, with the last one in Saskatchewan in 1956 and the last one in Manitoba in 1952. Ontario has had only three, with the last one in 1921. Quebec has had two with the last one in 1980, but it has passed Bill 150 which provides for another one this year. New Brunswick has never had a referendum or plebiscite. Nova Scotia has had two, with the last one in 1929. There has been one in Prince Edward Island, in 1948. Newfoundland had three, all having to do with whether or not it should join Confederation.
Most of these provincial referenda or plebiscites had to do with subjects such as the prohibition of liquor, the introduction of daylight saving time, the application of the Lord's Day Act, or whether women should have the vote or not.
I bring up that history to point out that referenda and plebiscites while being rare in Canada are not unknown. We have had them on important issues, but never an issue as important as the unity of the country at this time.
I should also point out that in some countries they are used quite often. In Switzerland they have had over 300 referenda. Australia has had 40; France, 20; Denmark, 14. They are used quite often in the states of the United States. In the United Kingdom there has only been one referendum. That was an important one in 1975 on whether or not the United Kingdom should join the European Economic Community.
I refer to that history because a lot of people when they hear the word referendum get very up tight and feel it will be wrought with difficulties and risks. There are difficulties. It is very difficult to put some complex constitutional proposals to the Canadian people in a referendum.
It is not a simple matter. There are risks and it is difficult but it has been done before. It was done on a very complicated matter in the United Kingdom with respect to the European Economic Community in 1975.

May 19, 1992
Government Orders
I believe that the positive elements outweigh the risks and the difficulties in these matters. By the way, so did the two parliamentary committees which recommended the possibility of a referendum, the Beaudoin-Edwards committee and the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee, in recommending that the Canadian people be consulted on constitutional proposals.
There are reasons that I believe the positive elements outweigh the risks. First of all, the Canadian population felt cynical after the collapse of the Meech Lake proposals. The process by which the governments of Canada examined the Meech Lake proposals, behind closed doors, sometimes as the Prime Minister said, rolling the dice on the future of the country and all that sort of rhetoric, extremely upset the Canadian people. They felt that this is our Constitution, this is how we give authority to governments and we should have something to say about it.
Even though it is complex and even though it is difficult, the final say on these matters should be with the Canadian people. Beyond that, why it is important is that it can settle the matter once and for all. If a government approves or disapproves of certain constitutional proposals, that government is always open to question as to whether or not it really represented the people of its province.
If the country goes down the drain as a result of the way one provincial government votes or does not vote especially behind closed doors at a federal-provincial conference, there will always be doubt in our minds as to whether the country broke up over some whim of a government or partisanship that should not have been present.
On the other hand, with a referendum, the people will decide, not the governments. I should say, they will at least give their advice. It will be up to the governments to legislate on that advice, but at least they will have the formal very clear-cut advice of the population. That having been said, it will settle the matter in a much more definitive way, not perfectly, but in a more definitive way than has been done in the past.
To conclude, as I said, we in the Liberal Party support the principle of this bill, that there be a referendum on
constitutional proposals, that the Canadian people be involved in approving of such constitutional proposals.
However, we want to see changes in the bill. We believe that there should be stricter limits on the spending of money by parties involved in the referendum, so that it is a fair process.
We also want to see provisions in the bill that provide for not only a national result but also regional results and that no question be carried without the support of the regions.
We will be looking at the process very closely, what happens in committee, whether the government is flexible, whether it is willing to accept amendments.
We will also want to see the legal opinions I referred to as to why financial controls would be against the charter. We doubt that and we want to see the legal opinions.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened with great care to my hon. friend who has served this country with distinction in many capacities, most recently in this context on the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee. I have a couple of comments and two or three questions for him.
First, he referred to the question of financial controls. He suggested it was lamentable that there are no financial controls on plebiscite spending within this bill. He was a member of the government which drew up Bill C-9 in 1978. Would he not agree that that bill also provided for no particular spending limits. In fact, I think under clause 8 of old Bill C-9 if a group was registered under that bill, in a referendum or plebiscite campaign then the sky was the limit.
There may have been some good reason for that in 1978 and some good reason today. I know he follows very closely the distinguished columnist William Johnson in the Montreal Gazette.
Mr. Johnson writing last Friday said: "Elections lead to corruption if ambitious people have unlimited money to buy their way to office. Personal ambition requires spending constraints but plebiscites are not fuelled by personal ambition. They do not put people in power for years able to wield that power for personal advantage, wealth and prestige. A plebiscite merely leads to an expression of opinion. It puts no one in power. Corrup-
May 19, 1992

tion is less likely because the plebiscite does not serve personal ambition as do elections".
The electorate is not stupid. As long as all views are sufficiently expressed, there is no reason to think the people will vote for one side because they hear that side's message more often. Trust the people, let everyone participate, that is the best course in a plebiscite.
My hon. friend also advocated there should be a majority in all regions of the country. I listened with care to him in that. He was perhaps looking at the recommendations of the committee which I had the honour to co-chair where a referendum would require a national majority and a majority in each of the four regions: Atlantic, Quebec, Ontario, and the west.
Discounting the wrath of British Columbia of not being regarded as a region unto itself, and I think his former leader might take issue with him on that particular omission, there is the other difficulty that immediately this report was tabled in June 1991, there was of course a response from at least two provinces saying that kind of approach to constitutional amendment is not acceptable. As my hon. friend knows, being a constitutional scholar, given our current amending formula under 41(e) no change can be made without the unanimous consent of the provinces. With great respect, I think the position of his party is an absolute non-starter.
The Beaudoin-Dobbie committee I think reflected that when it said simply: "We recommend that a federal law be enacted if deemed appropriate by the Government of Canada to enable the federal government at its discretion to hold a consultative referendum on a constitutional proposal either to confirm the existence of the national consensus or to facilitate the adoption of the required amending resolutions". There is no reference there to a regional majority.
Of course the people of Canada will inform themselves on the issues. They will interpret the results according to however they choose to interpret them. In the final analysis, given our present Constitution, the implementation of whatever decision is made, whatever advice is given by the people of Canada, must take place under the Constitution Act of 1982 which would require
Government Orders
the House of Commons, the Senate, and the legislatures of seven of the provinces constituting 50 per cent of the population to approve.
What I suggest to my hon. friend is that he is advocating overriding the present amending formula with his party's position or he is advocating entrenchment of this plebiscite in the Constitution; one or the other and I am not clear just what he is referring to.
Very quickly, my final comment refers to his House leader's comment about this bill being required to apply to all provinces. I would remind him in the old Bill C-9, clause 3(1) of the 1978 bill had identical wording. There was wisdom in 1978 as well as in 1992.

Mr. Speaker, my hon. colleague raises some good points that should be dealt with. First of all, Bill C-9 which was a Liberal bill in 1978 as he said, did not provide for limits but that bill was not passed. It was objected to from many sources. It was before the referendum of 1980 in Quebec. I think because of the various objections to it the government did not proceed with it, did not push it through Parliament, and did not pass it.
Personally, I believe having gone through the experience of the referendum of 1980 and seeing what has happened in other elections, the spending limits are necessary. They are necessary not only to ensure a fair referendum and plebiscite but to make sure the plebiscite is perceived by all Canadians as being fair.
While the provision may not have been in Bill C-9 in 1978, that bill was not passed. I think looking at the situation now, we do require spending limits. I would be very adamant on that. I think they are as important with a referendum bill as they are with the Elections Act for the House of Commons where we do have spending limits and we are going to improve the spending limits.
My hon. friend referred to comments by William Johnson in which he, in his column, differentiated between financial controls for elections to Parliament as opposed to financial controls for a referendum. He said that personal power was at stake in the one, but not in the other. That is true.

May 19, 1992
Government Orders
Again, the reason I propose and our party proposes spending limits is not because there is an element of personal power involved. It is because it must be perceived by all participating, especially by the side that will lose eventually-one side will lose-that the process has been fair.
I point out to my hon. friend that in 1942, the losing side, and I am not discussing the merits of the question, was overwhelmingly in Quebec. The "no" side was not even allowed access to Radio-Canada and the CBC, the public broadcasting network that they paid for with their taxes.
When the result came in, they perceived the result as being unfair. They may have lost anyway, but the fact is if you do not have the spending limits and the spending controls and you lose, there is always the accusation such as we in this party firmly believe that in the 1988 election the pro-free trade elements in Canada bought that election.
We firmly believe that, and nothing you say over there will change our mind. If there had been better financial controls-let me put this argument to you-on third party advertising and we had lost, we could not have used that as an excuse in accepting the result. I am telling you that it is very important when our country is at risk, that once the referendum is over those who have lost as well as those who have won will be able to say: "Nobody bought the result". It is not a question of personal power buying the result.
On the regional majorities, again by looking at our history and the two national plebiscites that we had in 1878 and in 1942, there were vastly different results in Quebec from the rest of the country. After it was all over, it was perceived as unfair, even though they were not binding in those cases. The referendum on conscription was not binding. It was the plebiscite.
Parliament was still supreme. It still had to legislate, but there was heat generated. The political heat and the passions of individuals in all parts of the country were very significant and they will be again. To say simply that the results are not binding legally does not really get to the core of the matter. The core of the matter is that politically, those results will have a lot of significance. Consequently I think it is much better to say in advance that there must be a majority not only in the country but in the regions.
I agree with my friend that there is a question as to where the regions should be-
