Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to have this opportunity to speak on Bill C-81, an act to provide for referendums on the Constitution of Canada.
I am particularly pleased because I served as did many other members of this House and of the other place on the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee on the renewal of Canada. That was a rare opportunity and a rare experience which we all learned a great deal from. I refer to that because I think it is important that we think about what the real goal is here.
The goal here is to renew this country, to renew Canada in a way that is meaningful, in a way that stands the test of time. As a result, I think that issues such as the referendum legislation which we have before the House today are an extremely important element of a whole series of initiatives, the end result of which is the renewal of our country.
I am also pleased to speak today because I have returned from the riding over the weekend. I can tell you that in my riding of Macleod and in the town of High River on Saturday, there was a tremendous show of support, interest and love for Canada. The right hon. Joe Clark was the guest of honour for the Little Britches Parade. There were 6,000 or more Canadians out there, all waving their little Canadian flags, showing their great support and love for this country. I can say that in the riding of Macleod, there is a great deal of interest in renewing this country, showing support for Canada. It was truly heartening to see that last Saturday.
This historic legislation has many facets and potentially far-reaching implications. While the government has yet to determine whether the actual holding of a referendum would be beneficial in assisting us in achieving national consensus, we must be prepared for such an eventuality.
What are the objectives of this legislation? Clearly, it is important to have in place a law that will allow this consultation to occur with the greatest possible efficiency and effectiveness. The law must allow the vote of the people to occur in a process that ensures the integrity of the process and the integrity of the result, while minimiz-
May 19, 1992

ing the hurdles to the exercise of that franchise by the people of Canada.
This bill meets that objective through its reliance on our tried and true experience with the Canada Elections Act and by giving the role of superintending the referendum process to the independent Chief Electoral Officer of Canada.
The other main objective of the legislation, an objective to which I will direct my remarks today, is that of fairness in the referendum campaign. I believe it is trite to say that a referendum campaign which is conducted without a sense of fairness of the process that leads to the answer of the referendum question deprives the result of legitimacy and negates the whole exercise. Fairness is critical to the campaign and must be reflected in the enabling legislation which governs any such campaign.
Fairness is a concept that is sometimes difficult to define in words but always easily recognizable in practice. When we think of fairness we think of something that is unbiased. We think of equitable opportunity. Of course, key to the fairness concept is the notion of playing by the rules. Bill C-81 exemplifies these elements.
The registration requirements of the bill are a case in point. As hon. members know, no person or group other than a registered referendum committee can incur referendum expenses during the referendum period in excess of $5,000. Therefore, while participation is welcomed from all Canadians, there is a requirement that one must register with the Chief Electoral Officer where one intends to spend over $5,000.
The registration procedure is set out in clause 13 of the bill and is quite straightforward. There are provisions that ensure fairness in the registration process itself. For example, the Chief Electoral Officer is required to examine applications for registration in the order he has received them and, second, provisions to guard against confusion in the name of a referendum committee are there in order to avoid confusion between committees or as between a committee and a federal or provincial party.
What the registration regime brings with it are two essential ingredients. Those essential ingredients are accountability and transparency. Accountability for larg-
Govemment Orders
er sums of money expended by these committees is ensured through the requirements for the use of auditors, a chief agent and for the keeping of books and records. Returns must be made detailing expenses incurred, contributions received, et cetera, much as is the case during an election campaign.
In addition, the law will require that those contributions received in excess of expenses must either be returned to contributors or, if that is not possible, to the Receiver General of Canada. This will protect against the misuse of funds by unscrupulous individuals.
Transparency is also present in that the bill requires that any contribution received from individuals, corporations, trade unions, political parties and other groups that exceed $250 must be reported. In this way contributions to registered referendum committees and the committees themselves will know that contributions and expenses over certain amounts will be matters of public record. This is as it should be. This does not limit participation of Canadians or the expression of their views.
It does, however, allow Canadians to see who the financial participants were. This is of tremendous importance for the public's confidence in the outcome of a referendum.
I would like to turn to another thrust of the bill that I believe is laudable and that has fairness as its hallmark. This bill makes available to both sides of any referendum question free time for broadcasts on networks in order to get the message of both sides out without the barrier of cost and in prime time. This is a very significant initiative, a very significant part of this legislation.
Three hours of broadcasting time in prime time will be split equally between those registered referendum committees that support the referendum question and those committee that oppose the referendum question. This provides the essential fairness. The broadcasting arbitrator and an impartial official appointed pursuant to the Canada Elections Act will allocate the time available to registered referendum committees that have applied for registration before the 27th day before polling day; all committees that have indicated their wish to be considered for an allocation of free time.

May 19, 1992
Government Orders
To guide the broadcasting arbitrator, certain criteria are set out in the bill which will rely upon, among other things, the consideration of whether the allocation would be equitable with regard to the different views expressed on the referendum question, ensuring that there is a fair distribution of time and second, the consideration of the public interest in fairness to the referendum committees.
Again, fairness is explicitly recognized when the bill lists the factors the broadcasting arbitrator must take into account in deciding the broadcasting time that is to be made available to the various committees. Clause 24(4)(b) of the bill requires the broadcast arbitrator to take into account that any broadcasting time should be made available fairly throughout prime time.
This means that one committee cannot end up with broadcasting time in the middle of the night and somebody else in prime time. Everybody has to have fair time. That is a very important part of this process.
On the the same subject, it is also important to note that the bill requires the sponsor of referendum advertising to be identified when that advertising is aired. Similarly, printed advertisements will have to show the name of the sponsor. Again, this is a fair provision to help Canadians avoid confusion as to who is transmitting the message involved and to ensure transparency of the financial side of things. Those are important aspects of this initiative.
I would like to turn to other evidence of fairness in the process established by this bill. All hon. members of this House know the importance of the men and women who work on compiling and revising the electoral lists in an election campaign and the importance of the other men and women who make the campaign work as scrutineers and volunteers. The bill provides that the returning officer shall appoint the enumerators, revising officers and revising agents.
Given the fact that during a referendum campaign there are no candidates, the apparatus in the Canada Elections Act that allows candidates to have their agents present at the polling stations cannot be directly imported into a referendum campaign. Instead, in the interest of fairness, the law will provide for the appointment of two persons to act as witnesses for each polling stations. These witnesses will be appointed by the returning officer who must, as far as possible, select a person who supports the questions and a person who opposes the questions. These individuals will take an oath of office and will have all the rights and obligations of a candidate's agent under the Canada Elections Act.
The presence of these witnesses at the polling stations in electoral districts will reassure us that the fairness and the integrity of the referendum process will not only be integral to the taking of the consultative vote, but will also be seen and very visible to all Canadians.
A similar practice will be utilized for revising agents who are appointed by the returning officer.
Here again, the bill stipulates that revising agent pairs should, as far as possible, be comprised of a person who supports the question and a person who opposes it.
The bill provides as well that electoral lists will be made available on request to the designated agents of a leader of a federal or provincial party, or a registered referendum committee in the electoral districts. This provision, too, helps evoke confidence in the process, as both sides of any referendum question will have this crucial information available to them for the conduct of the referendum.
Another example of the element of fairness incorporated into the proposed law is the recount part of the bill, which allows electors to attend a recount, representing those who support and those who oppose the question.
Finally, I would like to refer to the statute which is the basis of the scheme that will be used to conduct the referendum campaign. The bill takes relevant provisions of the Canada Elections Act into the referendum process. Clearly, the Canada Elections Act is the foundation upon which this bill would operate. When one speaks of fairness in the conduct of an election campaign, one immediately thinks of the Chief Electoral Officer of Canada and his very able and excellent officials who work tirelessly to ensure that campaigns unfold in a way that is the epitome of fairness in an unbiased approach.
Canada is the envy of the world, and the counsel of the Chief Electoral Officer is often sought internationally by other countries whose electoral systems are not up to the same standards and which are seeking the highest standards possible. We are fortunate to have a Chief
May 19, 1992

Electoral Officer, with all the accumulated expertise in his office, to oversee any potential referendum.
Let us not forget all the provisions in the Canada Elections Act that will be drawn upon and that work when we assess the fairness mechanisms in this enabling legislation. For example, let us remember such sections of the Canada Elections Act that deal with the qualification of electors and residency requirements, ballot papers and ballot boxes and safekeeping, polling stations and fairness procedures of polling day, the initialling of ballot papers, and no impeding of electors. There are a lot of things that we take for granted in the course of running a fair and open election. Other aspects are secrecy of voting, maintenance of peace and good order, the counting of the ballots in a fair and open process and the prohibition of broadcasting from outside Canada.
The fairness mechanisms of this bill are also backed up by offence provisions so that they can be enforced effectively.
Today is an important day as we debate the provisions of Bill C-81. We are setting the stage for a possible public consultation of historic proportions. We have a law that respects the Charter of Rights and Freedoms by allowing maximum participation and freedom of expression, while being fair and encouraging an open, transparent and accountable process.
With this newly-created opportunity to vote in a possible future referendum comes the responsibility to ensure that the vote is done according to rules that are clear and fair. I believe this is such a law. I believe this bill strikes the right balance. I hope that if a referendum occurs Canadians will participate in this great opportunity to be even more involved in national renewal. Canadians have to date received unparalleled opportunities to participate and have joined in this renewal process with vigour.
I am also mindful of the words of the Special Joint Committee on a Renewed Canada, a committee on which I served and spoke of earlier. It recommended that a law be enacted if deemed appropriate by the Government of Canada to enable the government at its discretion to hold a consultative referendum on a constitutional proposal, to either confirm a national
Government Orders
consensus or facilitate the adoption of the required amending resolutions.
This bill will ensure that should it be decided that a referendum is required, we will have the tools available to hold such a vote in a fair and appropriate way.
As I mentioned earlier, this is but one step along the road to renewing this country, to giving Canadians the opportunity to feel better about their country, to feel fully a part of this country. When we get into some of the substance of the issues it is an opportunity for western Canadians like myself to feel that our part of the country is fully responded to and is fully reflected in the national character of this country. The same is true for the people of Quebec, the same is true for aboriginal Canadians and the same is true for all other Canadians.
I hope that if this is necessary, Canadians will participate in this referendum in a full and meaningful manner because this could be a historic opportunity if it is deemed appropriate.

Mr. Speaker, unfortunately the more I hear about this bill, the less impressed I am with it and the more distressed I am that the government has not taken the trouble, in advance of this bill, to consult with all sides in this House effectively.
Let me ask the member about two particular provisions. He made much of the fairness of the bill and yet in the area of spending limitations, let me draw the member's attention to the provisions of the bill that you could drive a truck through.
The alleged limit on expenditure in clause 14 says that no person or group, other than a registered referendum committee, shall incur and set expenses exceeding $5,000. A registered referendum committee is defined by the most circular of all definitions: a person or group that intends to incur referendum expenses over $5,000. In effect, you can have any number of referenda committees, each of which is then authorized to spend as much as they like. How is that fair?
The government suggests there are legal limits. I defy the government to put forward a single, judicial decision which prevents the government or Parliament from regulating or limiting expenditures of third parties or referenda committees in an effective way. Parliament is

May 19, 1992
Government Orders
clearly entitled to do that. You will not be able to find a single legal opinion to the contrary.
Second, and I would ask the member to comment on this as well, section 3 of the act gives to the Governor in Council, i.e. the cabinet, the authority to consider proceeding with the referendum if, in its opinion, it is in the public interest to do so. The question comes back to Parliament for approval but not the decision to proceed with the referendum. On a constitutional issue of this kind, surely it should be up to the Parliament of Canada to decide on whether to proceed with the referendum because governments, being who they are, will proceed in part on their definition of public interest and their political interests as well.
As the member said, it is critical that this process be seen to be fair and that there be genuine consultation on whether to proceed with the referendum and, second, that the procedures on finance limitations be fair.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the questions from the hon. gentleman from Victoria.
On the question of spending, it is the judgment of the government that the value of the freedom of speech, which is recognized in the Charter of Rights and Freedoms of this nation, is an important value which overrides other considerations. There is legal advice, I understand, which would suggest that we would have to be very careful about limiting the ability of Canadians to form their own committees to work on one side or the other of a referendum question. That value of freedom of speech is something which clearly this government and the House of Commons respect. It is a value which we would all want to hold high in this country.
On the question of whether to proceed, clearly my colleagues suggest that perhaps there would be partisan considerations which would come into effect.
I fully believe that the only factor that would be taken into consideration at the time of a judgment about this by the cabinet, by the Privy Council, would be the future of this country. I reject this outright because I have been through this process, through the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee in which I saw some interests and some members of the House trying at times to slip a little bit
away from the non-partisan attitude which was so central to the work of that committee.
I hope that no members of this House slip into partisanship at this critical time in our history because what we need to do is ensure that this country is united. We need to ensure that this country comes through this process in which Canadians respect one another, Canadians all are united in their support of a united country. Canadians must respect the process through which we arrived at this point.
I encourage all members not to be partisan. I encourage all members to take into account the importance of the country and I fully expect that the cabinet will be doing that at the point at which it has to make a decision on whether to make use of this enabling legislation.

Mr. Speaker, on page 7 of the bill it says:
Where the polling day at a referendum is within one year after the
polling day at an election or a previous referendum, no enumeration
of electors shall be made for the purpose of the subsequent
referendum unless-
More or less it says that if we have an election a year after this referendum is being held, no enumeration will be done.
That might be fine in rural ridings but not in suburban ridings, in metropolitan ridings such as mine and the riding of my colleague from York West. Something like one-third of our constituents are apartment dwellers. Apartment dwellers tend to change within a year, a 25 per cent vacancy and turnover rate.
I am wondering if the hon. member sees the need for an enumeration during the election because we have heard great debates in the House about the unfairness of enumeration. My colleague from York North went back and forth a couple of times between ourselves and the Conservative members.
I am wondering if he shares with me the the idea that although there could be enumeration done during this referendum, there should be an enumeration in an election because all the parties involved, the other parties during the election, will not have a chance to make sure that the enumerations are done correctly, fairly. It could be to the advantage of a member and/or the government.

My question is does he not agree with me that because of great metropolitan cities like Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver we need to do an enumeration at the next election and this should be struck completely out?

Mr. Speaker, this is an interesting detail which my colleague raises and I suspect that the purpose here is to help ensure that the enumeration costs are kept to a minimum.
I believe in the legislation. There is an aspect which gives the Chief Electoral Officer some flexibility in the way in which he deals with the enumeration. If there is a problem in ridings such as that of my colleague in which there is a lot more mobility than there is in ridings such as mine, then I am sure the flexibility is there to afford the Chief Electoral Officer the opportunity to make those adjustments in between the time of the proposed possible referendum and any election in the subsequent year.
It is potentially a useful cost-saving exercise. There obviously will have to be flexibility in the implementation and I am sure the Chief Electoral Officer can do that.
Third, enumeration is clearly an important aspect of both the referendum and the election and I do not think the Chief Electoral Officer would be in a position that would limit his ability to ensure that those lists are appropriate, up to date, and ready for any potential federal election at which point I look forward to returning to the government side of the House.

Mr. Speaker, I think there have been discussions with members on all sides to permit the completion of at least the 20 minute portion past one o'clock. I believe if you ask the question you will find unanimous consent.

speechtext: The hon. members have heard the terms of the motion proposed by the member for York West. Is there unanimous consent?
Agreed.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext:
The hon. member for York West for a maximum of 20 minutes.
Government Orders

Mr. Speaker, I wish to thank the government members as well as the New Democratic Party and members of the Bloc Quebecois for their kind and generous co-operation.
Bill C-81 is no ordinary piece of legislation, particularly as we consider the time of the national unity dossier that is involving governments at all levels and Canadians from one coast to the other.
We on this side of the House accept the principle of a national referendum as a tool and a mechanism by which Canada and Canadians can legitimize constitutional reform. As has been expressed already by our House leader, on April 21 of last year, the Leader of the Opposition made public a nine-point constitutional agenda for national debate in this House and across the nation.
One of those points, and a very important point, was that any constitutional arrangement that was arrived at by the first ministers ought to be placed before all Canadians, regardless of whether that deal was a good one, a bad one or an indifferent one. At the end of the process, when governments crossed their ts and dotted their is, it was the belief of the Leader of the Opposition that because the Constitution of Canada, as the premier piece of legislation of this place, belongs to all Canadians, all Canadians are deserving of a voice and a stake.
It is no longer acceptable that only the chairman of the board or the chief executive officer or the board of directors be given the ability to dictate the future, but essentially that there are 27 million shareholders of this public company Canada who deserve a vote, a voice and a franchise.
We are pleased on that basis that the government has put before the House this piece of legislation, particularly as we concern ourselves with what went wrong on the Meech Lake round. It was not only a question of substance that caused consternation among Canadians, but the process of back room, secret, roll the dice dealings that undermined any integrity and confidence in the system.
My only point along this line was the hope that the government would have accepted at least one of the Leader of the Opposition's points on the referendum early enough so that a committee could have been stuck months ago with respect to preparing the legislation rather than the seemingly mad rush to try to

Government Orders
complete this in the next number of weeks and months before the House rises. It would have served the public interest much better had we taken that initiative some months ago.
In principle, this piece of legislation is acceptable in the sense of giving Canadians the ability to also dictate the future of their country. The bill at the same time is in need of serious amendments, serious modifications, to make this bill as fair and as up front as possible.
I would suggest seven changes. The first one is this national referendum should not be optional. The government House leader has said maybe, perhaps, it would be his intention or his preference not to have one at all. I am saying it should not be an option that Canadians perhaps or maybe will be a given franchise.
I believe a national referendum should be mandatory. Let us for certain give the opportunity to all Canadians to express themselves on the constitutional arrangement that first ministers will arrive at in a number of weeks and months. In order for constitutional reform to be truly legitimate, I believe this tool of a national referendum should be mandatory and guaranteed as the final part of this constitutional process.
In terms of the possibility or options, this piece of legislation should be enacted. A national referendum should take place regardless of the size or shape of the constitutional arrangement.
Point two is that currently in the bill there is a sunset clause of three years which means that at the end of the three-year process this bill will die. That should be changed. The national referendum in terms of major constitutional arrangements should be a permanent mechanism. What is wrong with offering Canadians a say on the future of their country after all?
I believe Canadians are tolerant, educated, interested, mature enough and deserving of an ability to be actively involved and engaged in deciding and shaping the future of Canada's constitutional make-up. Therefore, it should not be grandfathered after three years. It should be a permanent mechanism so that the process that soured the Meech Lake round could never happen again.
It has been tried in other countries with a fair amount of success. Some people suggest constitutional arrangements are something too complex for the average Canadian. Based on the experience of other countries such as Australia, in which the citizens disposed of many options that they saw as unfit or unpopular and really came down with a bottom line, I believe Canadians are able to to do that. In many cases, they can probably do it much better than the elected representatives in terms of being viewers at a distance in trying to ascertain what is truly important as opposed to what is not important, or what is good or what is bad for the country. Put our faith in the hands of those 27 million Canadians and I do not think we will go wrong.
Point three is that the national referendum must be truly national. Currently the bill is written that if the referendum is held, it need only be held in one or more provinces. From my viewpoint, that is a very dangerous exercise.
If we have a national referendum, it must be held in each of the 10 provinces and 2 territories. If there is anything less than that, we cannot call it a national referendum because if we have a referendum by the federal government in one or two provinces and then provincial referendums in three or four and then no referendums in the remaining territories or provinces, what kind of a verdict will that yield?
You will have a situation potentially that the provincial referendum in the province of British Columbia, for instance, will be a very different question than the provincial referendum held in Alberta or even than the federal referendum held in three other provinces. What we will see is a chequerboard of referendums that will yield different conclusions based on different questions. I would submit that it would not offer clarity, it would not offer solid direction but would only cloud the issue and lead to a multiplicity of interpretations which would undermine any sense of national purpose that a national referendum can mobilize.
I would suggest that the government House leader and his parliamentary secretary and the members of the government think of the consequences of having a referendum in only some parts of the country. We cannot have a part-time referendum in various spots along the way. We need one question asked of all shareholders of this country and only then can we ascertain what direction the electorate has imposed

on its elected leadership. Anything short of that will drain the integrity or clarity from a referendum.
Point number four concerns what has already been well mentioned, the lack of any spending limits or regulations. Currently the bill only has the stipulation that if any individual or organization gives more than $5,000 with respect to the referendum, he or she or the group must register. There are no ceilings attached to expenditures in the national referendum. That is a very dangerous situation because many Canadians will see the referendum as being fair only in direct relationship to what one group or individual can spend.
We saw in the general election of 1988 the concern, the consternation and the damage that was done by third party advertising. On the one hand, the election act controlled what individual candidates and parties could spend, yet third parties had no limits on what they could spend on television advertising, newspaper advertising, radio advertising, general flyers going around to homes or at general meetings that were organized. They had carte blanche.
If it was wrong, and many dispassionate observers would say it was very wrong, a national referendum that would have serious consequences for the future of this country should not be put at the whim of any group or clique of individuals who would have an ability to spend whatever they wished in order to influence and dictate the outcome of the national referendum.
The message coming from Canadians is that this issue should not be dictated by the depths of one's financial pockets, it should be up front. It should be clear and the same for all Canadians. There should be a ceiling by which all Canadians' actions vis-a-vis the referendum is governed.
This issue is crucial enough, given the history of this constitutional dossier, to be up for grabs depending on the power that individuals have with respect to expenditures. That goes to the very heart of how Canadians view this referendum. All matters should be fair, up front and equal for all.
Point number five is along the same lines as the whole question of expenditure limits. I would suggest there be a component of public financing through the
Government Orders
tax credit. I believe there are a number of Canadians across the country who might not have the ability or the time to get involved with any of the referendum campaigns, writing letters, presenting papers, presenting a brief or participating in a rally but they would be prepared to spend $25, $30, $50 for Canada. I believe that those individual Canadians in my riding, in the ridings of hon. members from all sides, should be encouraged to participate and put their $25 down for a united country and be supported through the tax credit as they are when they contribute to any of the political parties across the country. I do not think we should exclude average Canadians, despite the tough economic malaise that is gripping the country, from saying: "I believe in Canada and my way of showing it is to give $25 to the committee supporting a strong united Canada".
I urge the government to take a look at, not spending by governments in the campaign, but allowing Canadians to use the tax credit so that they can participate and also get a tax break based on their involvement come tax time next year. I think that is fair and it would show an openness to involve all Canadians.
Point number six is that we should have the prerequisite not only of a national majority with respect to the question but a double majority in this bill. It should be a majority across the board, across Canada, plus a majority in each of the four defined regions, namely the west, Ontario, Quebec and Atlantic Canada.
If the answer coming back from the majority of Canadians is for a strong united Canada with a strong national government, it would be beneficial and very reassuring if we had a double majority. In that way, no region of the country would feel that it had been coerced or pressured or ignored by other Canadians in other regions of the country wanting something that that particular region was uncomfortable with.
Therefore, it would be a win-win situation; it would be a national majority complemented by majorities in each of the four regions of the country. It would give rise to the feeling that the referendum had played the politics of inclusion rather than the politics of exclusion. The feelings of alienation that come from that type of arrangement would be gone.

Therefore, Mr. Speaker, a double majority would be an investment in good will and in feeling that everyone is a part of this Constitution which, after all, belongs to all Canadians.
My last point, point number seven, is that we should have a change in how the opposition parties are consulted. It was mentioned today by our House leader that there was no consultation, despite the promises of the Prime Minister and the Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs, in the legislation before us today. I believe that there ought to be consultations from here on in, particularly if we have a national referendum-and I hope we do-and particularly in the writing of the question.
We saw in the Quebec referendum in 1980 what a nebulous question can do to a population and, indeed, to a country. I believe the question is important enough to merit the close scrutiny of this Parliament and to involve the three federal political parties in a joint venture, if you will. We must ensure that the question which inevitably will be asked is a clear one, an honest one and a relevant one so that the result will will be of a positive, clear, concise nature. We should not play with the wording of the question to get a particular result. It should be clear and up front and its result should be equally clear.
I am pleased that I was given the opportunity of sharing with the House a few of the important issues that this member for York West sees in this legislation. I welcome the bill in principle. It is long overdue. I do have some reservations, essentially defined by those seven issues. I hope in the committee studies following second reading we can iron them out so that at third reading we can debate a bill that is significantly stronger and fairer for all Canadians.

350TH ANNIVERSARY OF MONTREAL

Mr. Speaker, last weekend, Montreal celebrated its 350th anniversary. The valiant men and women who faced the adversity of impossible situations had the faith and courage needed to make that adventure an outstanding success.
The 350th anniversary of Montreal is also a celebration for Quebec and all of Canada. Montreal, the world's second-largest French-speaking city, takes pride today in its uniqueness in Canada. It is a place where many ethnic communities live together in mutual respect.
As our Prime Minister, among other dignitaries, said, much of Canada's history can be traced back to Montreal. Congratulations to all who contributed to these celebrations and to the development of this beautiful metropolis.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday was International Museums Day and I take this opportunity to salute Canada's museums, which are dedicated to the preservation and presentation of our culture, our heritage and our valued treasures.
According to StatsCanada there are over 2,200 museums and related institutions which welcome over 57 million visitors each year. Our museums are nonprofit institutions. They are a vital link, reflecting the world's varied cultures through many different mediums. They add and give pride and a sense of identity to our citizens while contributing to our economy and tourist industry.
However, the Minister of Communications has not given any assurances that grants and services to non- federal museums will be retained by the federal government in the constitutional negotiations.
May 19, 1992

The Standing Committee on Communications and Culture unanimously recommended that the Museums Assistance Program, the Cultural Initiatives Program and other heritage programs be retained by the federal government while acting in close consultation with the provinces.
What better time for the Minister of Communications to give the museum and heritage community the message that the federal government will stay in business and support them through grants and services to these non-federal museums.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I wish to point out the national launching of Canada Fit Week, which will take place tomorrow at noon in Confederation Park in Ottawa. It is the greatest celebration of active living in the world.
On the theme of celebrating the active life, the hon. Minister of State for Fitness and Amateur Sport, will officially launch this event that runs from May 22 to 31. This unique activity was made possible with the co-operation of the federal, provincial and territorial governments and the participation of 18 national organizations and private-sector sponsors, and for a good reason: the success of active living has been clearly demonstrated.
Last year, more than eight million Canadians took part in over 16,000 activities. I call on all hon. members to participate in the launching of Canada Fit Week and related activities in their communities so that it will again be an outright success.

Mr. Speaker, last Friday, the government tabled its bill on referen-dums in Canada. Just as in 1978, the federal government's fear of letting Quebec decide its own future is behind this bill.
Just like the Liberals then, today's Conservatives, including those from Quebec, refuse to let Quebec make its own decisions. Although the Conservatives voted at
their convention last year in favour of a motion by a Quebec member, the hon. member for Louis-Hebert, recognizing Quebec's right to self-determination and have boasted about it so much, the government has decided to ignore it.
Obviously, Mr. Speaker, the purpose behind all this is to avoid holding a general election, since the Prime Minister thinks it is too soon. Too soon for whom? For the Conservatives, not for us in the Bloc Quebecois. We are ready and we have been demanding an election again and again. Call an election now and you will see how Quebec will answer.

Mr. Speaker, according to friends and foes, the explosion that destroyed the Morgentaler clinic yesterday on Harbord Street in Trinity-Spadina was caused by a bomb. If so, that act of violence will not stop abortions.
Abortions arise in the pattern of violence toward women: not only rape and gender directed murders but systemic pressures on women as child bearers. Our North American society not only peddles sex as a commodity but too often it abandons the woman who bears a child.
Low wages and unemployment, husband desertion and non-support, shortages of good child care for children of working mothers and shortages of decent affordable housing condemn many single mothers and their children to poverty and humiliation.
The bombing of abortion clinics in the United States has not stopped abortions, nor has the threat of jail for women or doctors stopped them in Ireland.
We need good sex education, good and available contraception, and respectful economic and social support for every woman bearing or raising a child.

Mr. Speaker, the Prime Minister went to Montreal this past weekend to remind people what it means to be a Canadian.

May 19, 1992
To a cheering crowd, The Prime Minister quoted Sir John A. Macdonald: "Let us be English or let us be French, but above all let us be Canadians".
The Prime Minister also reminded people about the realities of politics in Canada. There are three national political parties in Canada which will field candidates in every province. There are two regional parties which will not even try to represent all of Canada.
In the next election you will not be able to vote against a Bloc Quebecois candidate in Toronto and you will not be able to vote against a Reform Party candidate in Trois-Rivieres and that is simply wrong.
The parties of the western separatists and the Quebec separatists will surely attract those people who are blind to Canada's history and intolerant of its realities. But as the Prime Minister said in Montreal, Conservatives and Liberals and New Democrats will work for Canada together.

Mr. Speaker, the problems created by the changes in the UI act by Bill C-21 continue to grow in number and severity, and as is usually the case in situations of this kind, the innocent and well-intentioned get hurt the worst.
Of particular concern right now is the Revenue Canada appeal system. A large number of people in my riding filed in good faith for UI benefits. UI referred these people to Revenue Canada for an eligibility ruling. They were refused because of interpretations of the terms "arm's length" and "contract of service". They then had to appeal through the Revenue Canada system.
For many this began last November. Six months later they have had no decision. The final stage of the appeal process is the Tax Court and it will not hear most of the appeals until the fall. That will be a full year of waiting for an answer from Revenue Canada.
Bureaucratic delays have forced innocent people into debt, in some cases debt which puts their homes in jeopardy.
People who had been told by the UI Commission, by Revenue Canada, and by various lawyers and accountants that their employment arrangements and business
structures were legal now find themselves in limbo with no answers coming from Revenue Canada.
People are into another earning period still not knowing what their legal UI status is.
Justice is not being served when a bureaucratic structure can play havoc with peoples' lives.
I ask the minister to intervene immediately, to speed up all stages of the appeal system, and to hold special hearings of the Tax Court in order to clean up the backlog.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I take this opportunity to remind members of the House and all Canadians that May is Cystic Fibrosis Month. Cystic fibrosis, or CF, is a genetic disease which affects the lungs and digestive system.
For the past 30 years, the Canadian Cystic Fibrosis Foundation and its many dedicated volunteers like Tim Hunter of the Calgary Flames, the honorary chairman, Mila Mulroney, and thousands of financial donors have been helping to support research and to provide much needed programs and services to CF sufferers and their families.
The theme for cystic fibrosis month is "We've never been so close to a cure. They've never needed your help more".
Tremendous advancements have been made since the 1989 discovery of the gene that causes cystic fibrosis. With our help, the next decade promises improved treatment for this terrible disease and even possibly a cure.
On behalf of the federal government, I invite all Canadians to support the work of this organization so that they may achieve success in finding a cure.

Mr. Speaker, co-operative housing provides shelter while offering a supportive environment and the opportunity to develop skills learned through co-operative management.
May 19, 1992

These are the words of the housing minister this past December and yet in the federal budget two months later the co-op housing program was axed.
I am sure all Canadians want to know why the government had such a sudden change of heart in those two months. Did it think that all the 165,000 people on waiting lists for co-op housing won the Lotto 6/49?
In justifying this decision, the government told us that it would be spending more on social housing but the budget reduced this commitment as well, from $97 million down to $70 million.
The objective of co-op housing is not to create public housing ghettos for the poor, it is to give them hope and a way out of this route. In this regard the program is a Canadian success story. It provides housing to moderate and low-income people, seniors and the disabled. It fosters a sense of pride and community and does this in a very cost-effective way.
By cutting the co-operative housing program, the government has destroyed the pathway from poverty to self-sufficiency. I call upon the government to reinstate this vital and important program and to recognize the damage that its policies are doing.

Mr. Speaker, last Thursday the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans visited New Brunswick to announce a major initiative designed to promote the conservation and enhancement of recreational fish resources in Atlantic Canada.
The goal of the $5.7 million Educational and Public Awareness Program is to raise the level of appreciation, particularly among our young people, to the important role the fishery plays in the Canadian economy.
Co-ordinated through a number of organizations, including the Huntsman Marine Science Centre in St. Andrews and Memorial University in Newfoundland, EPAP is aimed at restoring the freshwater and coastal habitats for salmon, trout, mackerel, and smallmouth bass.
The initiative is based on the grassroots participation of local people and native groups who will play an active role in identifying and taking action on habitat problems.

Mr. Speaker, during the past weekend more than 500 parliamentarians from North America and Europe, including the republics of the former Soviet Union, met in Banff for the influential North Atlantic Assembly.
The beauty of Banff, the warm hospitality of Alberta, and the efficiency of the organization lead by the indefatigable member for Scarborough East, put the delegates in a receptive mood to hear a creative message from Canada on the issues before the conference. But no senior minister of the government took the opportunity to speak to the plenary session.
Where was the Minister of National Defence? It was his duty to represent Canada at that conference. A great opportunity was missed to set out Canada's views on the future security arrangements for Europe and North America, on the vital need for even sharper cuts in arms, for conflict prevention measures.
Canada has a stake and an interest in these issues. It was a disgrace that the minister was not there.

Mr. Speaker, Canadians must reject calls for spending limits and umbrella committees to be put into the referendum legislation. We must be mindful of the words of U.S. Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas, who said on June 24, 1957:
Free speech is not to be regulated like diseased cattle and impure
butter.
On June 18, 1986 U.S. Supreme Court Justice William Rehnquist said:
In a modern democracy, to resist political spending is much like
allowing a speaker in a public hall to express his view while denying
him the use of an amplifying system.
Let us not muzzle the free voices of our nation. Canadians are mature enough to make their own judgments on this or any other issue.

Mr. Speaker, this evening the National Capital Alliance on Race Relations is organizing an assembly of Canadians against racism here on Parliament Hill. Local religious and community leaders, business, labour, politicians and citizens will gather to express support in working to eliminate racism in our national capital community and in Canada.
In light of the recent demonstrations and violence in Toronto and other Canadian cities following the riots in Los Angeles, it is critical to ensure that racism is not tolerated in our society and for all to speak out.
While it was one particular incident that sparked the deplorable violence and destruction, there are other causes of unrest; high unemployment, high drug use, large numbers of high school dropouts, illiteracy, hopelessness. Racial tension is but a part of a greater social malaise and we must all work at fixing the root causes.
The government must also commit to invest available resources for the elimination of racism, including an immediate lifting of the funding freeze imposed in this year's budget on the Canadian Race Relations Foundation.
I applaud the National Capital Alliance on Race Relations for its work and encourage Canadians to organize similar events.


350TH ANNIVERSARY OF MONTREAL

Mr. Speaker, who could not feel proud about the great events that took place over the weekend in Montreal? More than a million people celebrated the 350th anniversary of the founding of Montreal. French-speaking and English-speaking people joined those of other language backgrounds to celebrate a really distinct society together.
To mark the event, I would have three suggestions to make. First, settle the constitutional issue, with the leadership of the first ministers and the native people; second, make Bill 178 more flexible so as to allow bilingual signs in Montreal; third, have the federal government work with the unions, Montreal City Hall
and the Government of Quebec to revive Montreal's economy. If we work together, Mr. Speaker, we will all celebrate Montreal in grand style 365 days a year.

Luckily a demonstration by local unemployed people in Cornwall restored part of the funding to end the present school year, but countless other individuals in Hawkesbury, Alexandria, Cornwall and elsewhere are still going to be denied the usual benefits.

speechtext: Mr. Speaker, there have been some discussions and I believe there is an understanding at this point in time that we will have testimonials with respect to the situation in Nova Scotia and the coal mine.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise on behalf of the Government of Canada, I am sure all members of this House and of the people of Canada to express our most heartfelt sympathy to the families and friends of the 26 miners who died in the Westray mine in Plymouth, Nova Scotia as a result of the explosion of May 9.

Our thoughts and prayers have been with the community ever since, and are so especially today. A memorial service organized by the Pictou Council of Churches and attended by His Excellency the Governor-General and the right hon. the Prime Minister is under way in Pictou county at this moment. The service pays tribute to those who died and to the indomitable courage and spirit of all miners. Their loved ones have learned to face tragedy and somehow rise above it.
The families and friends of those who died as well as the whole community of Plymouth now face the painful task of carrying on without those whom they have lost so tragically. They do so in the knowledge that their community and in fact the country wishes to offer every assistance possible. We also pay tribute to the heroic efforts of the rescue teams who risked their lives in the hope of finding the miners trapped in the explosion.
Mining has played a significant role in the history of Nova Scotia and of Canada. These men will not be forgotten. As the late Helen Keller once said: "Although the world is very full of suffering, it is also full of the overcoming of it".

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I join with other members of this House to remember the 26 men who met sudden death at the Westray coal mine in Plymouth, Nova Scotia.
Death and disaster are all too familiar to the coal mining communities throughout this country. These men bring the total number of deaths in Pictou county, Nova Scotia to 272, yet for many in eastern and central Nova Scotia, the mines provide the only opportunity for meaningful work.
It is not pleasant work. It is hard and unsteady work. It can be dangerous and unhealthy but for many, it is their only way to enhance their economic opportunity. Miners are an indomitable breed. They do not shrink from the arduous nature of their labours nor from the dangers posed to health and safety. Their object is to earn an honest living for themselves and their families and they take these awful risks to do so.
Disasters like those at Westray mine are brutal blows, not just to families of the victims, not just to the communities in which they live but indeed to an entire nation. All Canadians feel the pain and join in the grief. We marvel at the spirit of the people, not only
Tributes
from the communities directly affected which united in support of the stricken families, but also those from all over Atlantic Canada who came voluntarily to Plymouth to risk their own lives in the valiant but futile attempt to rescue.
We know that as long as there is a demand for coal and as long as there is coal to be mined, there will be brave and honest men in Nova Scotia to do the work. There is a special spirit in the mining communities of Nova Scotia that marks that of mining communities everywhere, a spirit that was well summed up by a poet of Wales when he said:
Though they go mad, they shall be sane;
Though they sink through the sea they shall rise again;
Though lovers be lost love shall not;
And death shall have no dominion.
In the last few days, we have seen that spirit at work. The extended communities, of not just Plymouth or even just Pictou County but of all Nova Scotia and all Atlantic Canada have gathered around the stricken families. Especially impressive have been the courageous draggermen who so valiantly attempted the rescue. Many of these men came from my own constituency but they also came from various parts of Pictou County and parts of New Brunswick. To each and everyone I express the appreciation of the House for their heroic efforts.
This is the way of Nova Scotia's mining communities, resolution and strength in the face of adversity. The pain of the past is eased by the determination to build a better future.
Words alone cannot express the depths of our sympathy for the families, friends and communities who have suffered such tragic losses. So let us today offer our own personal prayers and sincere condolences to the families of these special men. And let us reassure these miners that their struggle was not in vain. We as a people shall never forget.

Mr. Speaker, on behalf of the New Democratic Party caucus and our leader, the member for Yukon, who is also at the memorial service today, I wish to offer our condolences to the families and the friends and the people of the community who are affected by the mining disaster.

As we say in war, people should not die in vain. I would hope that after this memorial service is finished hard questions will be asked as to why the mine was allowed opened when in 14 years 246 people died. There are many serious questions. They must be answered.

We hope that we will all learn lessons from their terrible death. Naturally, Mr. Speaker, like all of you, we want to join those who are at the memorial service to share our sympathy.

May 19, 1992

Mr. Speaker, when I advocated earlier today that another area needs modification, that was essentially in advocating a double majority.
We on this side of the Elouse, despite the good work by my hon. friend who was the co-chair of one of the two committees that he alluded to, and despite the complications of the amending formula, believe that a national majority, complemented by a majority in four regions of this country-the west, Ontario, Quebec and Atlantic Canada-would be a win-win situation and would preclude as far as possible any Canadians or provinces within one of those predescribed regions from feeling that a constitutional arrangement has been forced upon them by the rest of the country, despite that one region perhaps having reservations with the over-all package or with one particular element of that package.
Thus, in order to try to avoid any regional aspirations as being shut down by other Canadians or for some people to suggest in the patriation of the Constitution in 1982 that somehow Quebec was left out despite the fact that it was a sovereignist government that was negotiating with the national government, and despite the fact that the existing Prime Minister was a big cheerleader of the 1982 constitutional deal, this double majority would avoid those feelings of alienation or being left out of the constitutional arrangement.
What we are suggesting is that this mechanism would certainly improve from the procedural viewpoint the feeling that we have incorporated all Canadians and that we have not played the politics of exclusion and have pressured one region against the other, but that we are seeking a complementary double majority so that this country may be strengthened by this national referendum and that once and for all, in a successful and united way, we can put the Constitution behind us and address the economic challenges.

Mr. Speaker, we are very interested obviously in ensuring that all of the regions, western Canada, as well as other regions, have a voice when it comes to a referendum if that is the way we
go-

would all have to pass a majority in order to be interpreted as a success?

Mr. Speaker, what I put forward today with all sincerity was a formula that I believe would work better than simply having a national majority. Some members in the House advocate that British Columbia ought to be a region in itself. Some advocate that the two territories should be another region. I suppose we can have those debates without any final resolution.
I am trying also to inject a dose of practicality into it. We may be in a national referendum this summer or early fall.
What we are attempting to do is try to avoid the Meech Lake process that not only failed many Canadians in the substance but failed miserably in the process. Canadians felt that they were disenfranchised by a constitution they thought they owned, given that is the premier law of this land. We are saying that there happens to be 27 million shareholders of this public company called Canada and we should no long rely simply on the chairman of the board or the chief executive officer or the board of directors to have a strong voice. We are suggesting it is time for all Canadians to have that voice.
