speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a privilege to have the opportunity to intervene in this debate concerning the legislation which would put in place the regime for a referendum, should one be called for.
This flows from the recommendations of the joint committee, which I had the privilege of co-chairing last year, and the one co-chaired by my hon. colleague for Winnipeg South and Senator Beaudoin which reported at the end of February. It is a useful piece of machinery to have on the shelf, should the need arise, to establish a national consensus.
I am happy to observe that there appears to be a growing confidence among Canadians that the current process of constitutional renewal will reach a successful conclusion. After many months of debate, open discussion and private reflection there is good reason to

May 19, 1992
Government Orders
believe that Canada's future is brighter than that of yesterday. Tomorrow we will continue our steady advance toward achieving true and lasting constitutional reconciliation within the Canadian family.

We have many reasons to be optimistic. On several issues, positions have become more flexible. Important agreements have been negotiated. Increasingly, the meetings and discussions across the country in recent weeks have taken place in a true spirit of compromise. Our ultimate goal is a renewed federation in which all Canadians can feel at home. Every step that we take in that direction is another reason to stay together. Of course, we would all prefer the debate about the Canadian Constitution to be settled quickly and to stop taking so much energy.
Other priorities, like our economic growth and social development, also demand our attention. But we cannot really devote ourselves to these urgent matters until the issue of our national unity is resolved.
The constitutional process that we are now going through is starting to bear fruit; not dramatically, but gradually, some would say too slowly, but steadily, as Canadians make the effort to understand one another better and discover how much they have in common.
Nevertheless, we should not fall back into naive optimism. We must keep on working. We must maintain this feeling of urgency and the sense of commitment that made it possible for us to achieve these results.
The multilateral constitutional process in which we are engaged began only a few weeks ago. On March 12, in Ottawa, my hon. colleague, the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs, announced that the federal, provincial and territorial governments as well as the other national native associations had agreed to begin a new series of discussions. The purpose of this process was to prepare a package of constitutional amendments that could be presented to Canada as the result of consensus among all parties.
The representatives of the parties involved in these negotiations agreed on an optimum timetable that provides for possible agreement by the end of May. Since then, in order to succeed, the participants in the multilateral process have met almost every week, both at the ministerial and at the senior official levels.
No effort has been spared to ensure the success of this process and the results of each meeting have helped forge the consensus that Canadians want and deserve.

During the month of April ministers and the four national aboriginal leaders met in Halifax, Ottawa and Edmonton. This month they have already met twice, in Saint John and Vancouver, and they will be meeting this week in Montreal.
Next week participants will be meeting virtually the entire week in Toronto to build on the considerable progress which they have already made. Throughout this multilateral process, all parties have understood quite clearly that nothing will be etched in stone until the whole package has been completed.
The constitutional affairs minister has repeatedly stated that some decisions can only be made by first ministers, and that in accordance with Canada's constitutional amending formula, nothing is final until it has been approved by Parliament and the requisite number of provincial legislatures. Nevertheless, the tone of these meetings has been positive.
Issues have been tackled slowly but surely and there has been remarkable consensus in some of the most contentious areas. Participants in the multilateral constitutional process have demonstrated a genuine willingness to compromise and to accommodate each other's differences and this spirit bodes well for the successful conclusion of the Canada round.
I will review some of the progress which has been made. While most decisions are comparable to agreements in principle, they still provide a measure of difficult issues which have been tackled and the areas of consensus which have been forged. For example, ministers agreed in Halifax to recommend to their respective governments the entrenchment of the inherent right of aboriginal peoples to self-government within the context of the Canadian state.
At that same meeting there was also agreement that
the Senate should be elected, that it should not be a
confidence chamber and that Senate elections should be
May 19, 1992

for fixed terms. In Edmonton there was further discussion on the Senate and on aboriginal issues.
In addition, ministers and aboriginal leaders reached broad agreement on the principles of a social and economic union. There was a clear preference for returning to the earlier rules for giving provincial status to the existing territories. Those rules had allowed the decision to be made by a territory and the Parliament of Canada. The range of options on the Constitution's amending formula is being narrowed in order to meet the needs of all parties, including the concerns of Quebec.
Another important area of agreement in Edmonton concerned the Supreme Court. Ministers and aboriginal leaders agreed to recommend the entrenchment of the Supreme Court's composition, including three judges from the civil law tradition of Quebec, and on the principle of provincial participation in the appointment process.
Where provincial powers might be transferred to the federal government, there would be compensation. On spending power, there was agreement to adopt the language of Meech Lake with respect to reasonable compensation if they choose not to participate in national shared cost programs provided they undertake a program or initiative compatible with the national objective.
In May at the Saint John meeting there was further discussion on the Senate. Ministers and aboriginal leaders dealt with the Senate's power to ratify appointments. Ratification of senior appoints such as the heads of the CBC and CRTC would be spelled out through amendments to the laws under which they were established.
There was unanimous agreement that the Senate should reflect groups now under-represented in our political system. In Saint John there was agreement on 90 per cent of the legal language on the social and economic union. [DOT]
There was discussion of legislative interdelegation with an agreement in principle to allow the federal government to delegate some of its power to make laws in a particular field to a province and vice versa.
Government Orders
Most recently in Vancouver ministers agreed to recommend the creation of a new order of government to the first ministers. They agreed that the inherent right would be stated in a new proposed subsection of 35(1) and that this inherent right would exist within Canada.
The various agreements in principle and areas of consensus which I have just cited are significant steps forward. While I must re-emphasize that all participants in the multilateral constitutional process want to review these issues in the context of the complete package, nevertheless they show that real progress is being made.
As we move on to the final meetings in the multilateral process, Canadians have good reason to be confident about their future. For many issues a working consensus has developed on how to resolve questions that not too long ago seemed to defy solution.

Of course, we all want Quebec to return to the negotiating table. Recently, we have all had encouraging signals from the Government of Quebec. Premier Bou-rassa visited several provinces where he had bilateral discussions with his counterparts. This evening, the Government of Quebec will host a reception for participants at the multilateral meeting to be held in Montreal on May 20, 21 and 22.
I believe that these are veiy positive signs. The Government of Canada will spare no effort so that all participants can consider the results of this Canada round with satisfaction and pride in the work done. If, despite all this progress, the process could not result in full agreement, the federal government will go on to the next step, which would be made possible with this bill that we are considering today.
We would consult all Canadians in a national referendum. This referendum would be fair and give everyone an opportunity to express their opinion. It would be the culmination of the most extensive consultation exercise ever undertaken by a Canadian government.
This bill is a prudent precaution. I urge all hon. members to give it their full support.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the hon. member who just stated his support for Bill C-81, a bill that will enable the federal government to prepare for and hold a Canadian or almost Canadian referendum, since we are not sure whether this referendum will be held in all provinces, or

May 19, 1992
Government Orders
in all provinces except Quebec. It remains to be determined by our government.
I have the following question for the hon. member: Is he aware of the following statement by Mr. Roch LaSalle, made on January 31, 1979, in referring to the referendum legislation tabled in the House in 1979: "This national referendum bill is in my opinion nothing more than a political gadget. The Prime Minister, in the wake of this fiasco and monumental failure on the political and economic fronts, has designed this tool to enhance his image as the great saviour of Confederation".
I wonder whether the Conservative government endorsed this criticism. That year's Hansard is full of similar statements by Ms. Flora McDonald and the right hon. Joe Clark. They all said it was a monumental mistake.
In what way, therefore, is this referendum bill different? How is it different this time? The Conservatives are in power. They presented the same bill, I think, after having consulted Bill C-9, the old Liberal bill. How do these two bills differ?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank the hon. member for his question. He was asking what the difference is between the situation in January 1979 and the present situation and why statements by a former minister and the then Leader of the Opposition should reflect a situation different from that in which we find ourselves today.
He was the Leader of the Opposition in January 1979.
The situation is that we have had 13 years of rather chequered history pass between us since that time. This bill before us today is largely a technicality. The genuine software of any referendum initiative that is to be taken will be contained in the question itself. The member's own party acknowledges that through its not entirely unreasonable demands in that quarter.
The situation between 1979 and today has changed rather drastically. The mechanics of the bill can remain the same but the situation is very different.
We have had a Quebec referendum in the interim and we have had the remarkable situation of all the Quebec members of Parliament, including the Hon. Roch LaSalle, voting for Quebec's involvement in the Canadian constitution and for the patriation of the constitution and, if I am not mistaken, all the members of the Quebec National Assembly voting against it.
It cannot truly be said that Quebec had subscribed to the 1982 constitution.
Criticisms made of an initiative in 1979 or with an initiative in 1992 often do not relate to the mechanics of the bill, which is what I believe we are examining, the principle and the mechanics of the bill today, but rather the use to which that would be put.
If I could go right back in conclusion to the preamble to the hon. member's question, I can only conclude that he does not believe that the people of Canada ought to be consulted on this question or that the government should avail itself, that this House should avail itself, of the opportunity to put the question should that later be desired.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask the hon. member for Edmonton Southwest what he thinks of a statement made by Senator Gerald Beaudoin, with whom he co-chaired a certain committee; the statement, in a document on the constitutional aspects of the referendum is to the effect that electing a majority of pequiste members of Parliament in Ottawa for Quebec would have the same value as a referendum.
In view of this statement, I would like to know if the hon. member agrees with his co-chairman's statement which means that all we need is an election to find out what Canadians, and especially Quebecers, think?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have not seen the quotation that my hon. friend has cited. I have immense respect for Senator Beaudoin's capacity on questions of constitutional law, as I think do most if not all Canadians.
I would only respond by saying that the way to resolve our constitutional dilemma is not by having an election. It would be probably the last issue that might be addressed if an election were called today and we would be no closer to solving our constitutional problems.
May 19, 1992

There will be an election by November 21, 1993. It is then that those issues can be addressed. In the meantime, if there is a need to identify a national consensus on constitutional issues, then the bill before us, Bill C-81, will provide the means of establishing that consensus.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to speak against this bill. To begin with, I would like to say that in principle, I am not against consulting the Canadian people, I am not opposed to using a referendum to consult the residents of a city or town or province in Canada. As was already said, it is something like the GST. We are not against taxes as such, but the GST is not the right tax at the right time and the way it is collected is not fair. We can say the same thing about this referendum. We are not even sure that it will be held all across Canada, because the government House leader said that it might not be held in all provinces. This bill is not quite clear and we do not know exactly what we will vote on.
I think this bill is a fraud. It is expensive and it is also very provocative for the first ministers and even for native people. It is deceptive because it does not allow having yes and no camps as we had in the Quebec referendum in 1980. Furthermore, there is no spending ceiling. If I remember correctly, the federal government spent more than $17 million in 1980 to win majority support. This bill sets no spending limit. There is a symbolic limit, if you will, but no real limit in that millions of dollars can be spent.
As for what constitutes a majority, will it be a double majority or a single majority? No one knows. Lysiane Gagnon, who I think is an excellent columnist, wrote a report in La Presse of April 4, 1992 in which she said: "Besides the issue of interpreting the results, which is an insoluble problem" -she is talking about a Canadawide referendum -"with a single majority, Quebec's vote would be drowned out; with a double majority, the experience of the 1942 plebiscite is likely to be repeated; with a quadruple majority (meaning a regional majority in the West, Ontario, Quebec and the Atlantic), the risk
Government Orders
of fragmentation increases. If the native people are included, there could even be five majorities". Finally, Ms. Gagnon asks how the federal government could override the will of a whole region. If the native people voted against, would that mean the referendum would fail? I think that is an excellent question raised by Lysiane Gagnon in La Presse.
There is not only the issue of a double majority. There is also the question of free air time proposed by the federal government. They want to give the yes and no sides air time on television and radio and space in the newspapers as well, I suppose, I don't know, but they will give enough air time, probably on the CBC, for both sides to express themselves. But how will they choose the yes and no supporters, especially the no supporters? Will they choose them from the Reform Party? From the Bloc Quebecois? Will they choose other spokespersons? Who will choose whom?
If there is no real spending limit, one may ask how one can really have a fair, even-handed, open referendum. In fact, those who can give more money can buy more advertising. Even federal MPs can heavily influence a referendum because I think they have considerable resources just by virtue of being members of Parliament.
But something interests me more than that: Quebec has already said that is does not want to negotiate as one among eleven. But with a referendum, are we not starting to negotiate as one among 27 million? That is important, because I find that with a referendum-yes, the general public should be consulted. Most of the time, there is some polarization between those who are for and against the question. But, Mr. Speaker, I can tell you that is not the case here. The answer to our constitutional problems cannot be summarized in a yes or a no vote.
Excuse me, but that is so, unless you want to trivialize the question so much that it becomes meaningless. Are you for Canada? Are you for Quebec? It makes me think of Yvon Deschamps who said that what Quebecers want is a strong Quebec in a united Canada. That is true, but it is trite. It does not solve the constitutional problem. And how much will it cost? One million? No. Ten million? No. We will spend $108 million for this kind of super opinion poll that will decide what? It will settle nothing. I think that it is a mistake to propose a referendum at this

May 19, 1992
Government Orders
time, because besides being costly and not fair to all, it is provocative. How can a referendum be provocative?
I will tell you that the way I see this bill and the way it was presented by the minister, it was provocative. How can I say such a thing? It is veiy easy. He says that there cannot be real spending limits or umbrella committees for the yes and no sides because there would surely be court cases -yes, lawsuits -under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. But when a journalist -I think it was Mr. Fraser of The Globe and Mail -said, "Did you think of maybe using the notwithstanding clause?", the government House leader said, "Yeah, but you know that Canadians take a dim view of it." They may not like it, but the notwithstanding clause could have been used.
Look at the question. If the referendum is not held all across Canada, if it is held in the other provinces but not in Quebec, it will set a double standard. It means that Quebecers will be treated as second-class citizens. It would mean that Quebecers have no say in the matter. You cannot deal with Canada-wide issues, because the expression Canada-wide does not include Quebec.
If there was a suit based on the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, this would be a good opportunity for people from Quebec or elsewhere to say: Wait a minute. We would like Quebec to give its opinion on this.
If the government decides to hold a Canada-wide referendum without a double majority, will this help the constitutional cause? Will it help solve the issue? I do not think so. I think it will be more provocative for the Prime Minister and the aboriginal groups, but especially for the Prime Minister, because instead of doing his job and trying to make offers to Quebec, he will simply say: Listen, you do not trust us; therefore, we will wait until the referendum is over.
In my opinion, that is the mistake. I want to compel the Prime Minister of Canada and the provincial premiers to make offers to Quebec and to the rest of the country to really do their job, not at a cost of $108 million, but just do the job for which they were elected. It seems to me that once elected, this government decided that it could throw money at the problem; spend, spend and spend even more.
I can tell you about the Spicer commission. I can tell you about Beaudoin-Edwards. I can tell you about the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee. As a member of that committee, I was proud to work on a project in which we proposed what we saw as solutions. A referendum was not one of our first solutions. Mr. Speaker, if you read our recommendations, you will see that a referendum was one of the last recommendations made. There is a reason for this. It is because the present constitutional problem is not the fact that Quebec negotiates with 27 million Canadians, nor the fact that it negotiates with 11 people, but the fact that Quebec receives offers concerning which Bill 150 can be amended to enable us to vote on these offers, at which time the referendum on sovereignty would become null and void if we accept the federal offers.
But do not tell me that we will get federal offers in the context of a Canada-wide referendum. This is no place to make federal offers, and you know that. If we hold a Canada-wide referendum, we will ask questions on the division of powers. The division of powers is what Quebec is interested in. I am not talking of something like asymmetry; we have to define the division of powers.
Mr. Speaker, I can tell you that when we get to the division of powers, you will see that the rest of the country is not as generous as you may think and that this referendum is more than provocative. People will find a reason to vote against Quebec, not necessarily because they are against the idea of giving more powers; in fact, I found it rather amusing to watch the New Democrat leaders of Ontario, B.C., Saskatchewan, and even Yukon say that there will more powers to the provinces. This is a tendency that will pick up momentum, because it costs less, it is less centralizing and people are much more responsible with the monies and the programs that are theirs.
It is not on a technicality that I oppose this bill. My opposition is based on common sense.
We will have to take our responsibilities. As a Quebecer and a Montrealer, I know that the constitutional issue has been zigzagging a lot: the aboriginal groups have been clear, then not so clear, and then not clear at all. We cannot ask a question and call upon the ordinary Canadians to do our job. I support the idea of a referendum in principle. In the case of a municipality, before it undertakes a megaproject, yes. Why? Because
May 19, 1992

people can tell whether they are in favour or not of such expenses by simply answering yes or no.
Mr. Speaker, do you remember the last referendum held in Canada, more specifically in Quebec? I am talking about the latest referendum, not the one held in 1980? My friend from the Bloc Quebecois might remember the last referendum held in Quebec. I am referring to the referendum in the town of Rosemere. People had to answer yes or no to the question: Are you for or against bilingualism for our town? That was a clear question. People voted in favour of bilingualism. It is to their credit. But this will not happen with a Canada-wide referendum that is rigged, that offers no protection to people disagree, and that is provocative. Even so, are we stupid enough in this House to believe that a Clyde Wells or a Gary Filmon can be persuaded to vote in favour of this referendum because 49, 51 or 60 per cent of their population agrees? No, those premiers will do their job; they will vote for or against, depending on what they themselves believe. I think that the provincial ministers will find this very provocative. In fact, the premier of Saskatchewan did not appreciate the fact that the federal government wants to usurp his responsibilities through a referendum.
In 1979, the Liberals had a good cause. They wanted the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms to be passed. The Canadian population was rather in favour of Mr. Trudeau's idea, the Prime Minister at the time, of a Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. There was some consensus in the country. I believe it is a mistake for the Liberals and Conservatives to support this referendum today as a consultation tool, as it may destroy our country rather than make it stronger.
In the course of this debate, I have tried to be non-partisan, to truly see the problem as a Quebecer. I have tried to see the issue of a referendum by looking at what happened when other national referenda were held.
In conclusion, I would like to mention what happened on those two other occasions when a Canada-wide referendum was held. There was one in 1898. It dealth with prohibition and the sale of alcoholic beverages. What was the outcome? Forty-four per cent of the Canadian population participated in the exercise. Fifty-one per cent, a sober majority, gave their support.
Government Orders
However, in Quebec, 83 per cent of those who voted were against the idea.
Let us now turn to the plebiscite of 1942 on the issue of conscription. Mackenzie King used to say that this was not a binding process. He said that the government would not send Canadians to war. It was just a survey. Well, we hear the same thing today. This is not a binding process. Thlk to those who were sent to the front and you will see that it was truly a binding process.
Mr. Speaker, 70 per cent of Canadians were in favour of conscription, while 72 per cent of Quebecers opposed such a measure. The mayor of Montreal-we talk a lot about the mayors of Montreal these days-even went to jail because he opposed the idea. He went to jail because he felt betrayed by Mackenzie King. It is unfortunate that we don't have mayors like him anymore.

Mr. Speaker, I really appreciated the comments my colleague the hon. member for Chambly made about the Canadian referendum process. If I understood him correctly, he said he was against a Canada-wide referendum.
I would like to ask him if the same would apply to the Quebec referendum? If not, what is the difference between these two referenda?

Mr. Speaker, I do not think it will be the same in Quebec as in Canada because I think that the choice is clear in Quebec, very clear indeed. I would like the Quebec referendum to be twofold and ask, first, do you approve the federal proposals, if any, yes or no? Then, if the answer to the first question is no: Are you for the independence of Quebec, yes or no?
If the public response to the first question were: "Yes, we approve them. We are not at all happy. This is a partial victory, a temporary benefit, but we agree." Then, I think that a referendum on sovereignty would become useless. We would not need one. However, the Prime Minister, the natives, the native groups and we, in this House, must take a non-partisan look at the work we are doing and try to get, if at all possible, the premiers to approve the Beaudoin-Dobbie recommendations instead of putting the decision-making process on the back of the public at large.

May 19, 1992
Government Orders
I am for consultation and, as former president of a consumer protection agency, I could not be against it. However, I disagree with this form of referendum, because I think that it is an extremely expensive sham.

speakeroldname: Mrs. Dorothy Dobbie (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I was very interested to hear what my friend and colleague across the way had to say about the referendum. I was a little bit surprised at some of the things he mentioned. He said, for example, that people will find a pretext for voting against Quebec. It may be the translation that was inaccurate, because I know my friend has been very, very fair and non-partisan in this whole question of national unity.
If that is what he did mean, it is certainly not the impression that I got as we travelled across the country. I felt very much that Canadians wanted to reach out and accommodate Quebec in every possible way they can, and that the idea of tabling legislation for the possibility of a referendum is really a way of the federal government's responding to the "what ifs?", the possibility that there is no other way of bringing the whole country's opinion to bear in a positive manner on this very important issue.
I was also a little surprised to hear the member say that in the referendum there is no provision for people who have a dissident point of view. Again, it may be just a matter of the translation, but I was beginning to wonder if perhaps he was speaking on behalf of another party when he made that point. It tied in to something he had said earlier when he mentioned that he was very concerned about there not being any expenditure limit.
I cannot understand for the life of me why anybody would object to private citizens or the federal government doing everything within their power to try and convince the people of this country to stay together, to keep the country intact.
Why does the member object to private citizens or the Government of Canada's doing everything in their power to keep this country together?

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the question. Perhaps I got a bad translation because I really feel the government should do all it can to bring this country together.
I believe the way this referendum is presented, the way the bill reads, it will not do that. If we are to do our jobs as members of Parliament, as first ministers, as leaders of the aboriginal groups and First Nations properly, we can get over this difficult period without spending $108 million.
I do not believe this is a question of being against the people of Canada or for the people of Canada. In fact, I would hate to see a question on the ballot of this referendum asking if we are in favour of Canada or against Canada or if we are in favour of Quebec.
I do not know what the question will be but I disagree even more with this legislation in that fundamentally I do not think it is needed at this time. I think it is unduly provocative, $108 million is extremely expensive, and the message I am getting from across the country is that Canadians want us, NDP, Liberal, Conservative, Bloc Quebecois, and Reform to do our jobs.
Our job is not that whenever we get into some difficulty because we perhaps cannot convince quickly enough the first ministers or others to lay it out across the board, across Canada, to give the problem to the Canadian people.
In those provinces where we will have two referenda, what is the percentage that really applies? If we have a referendum with 40 per cent of the population supporting the same question in one province and the federal question has the support of 60 per cent, does that mean the federal question won? What does it mean exactly?
There are a lot of problems here and I am glad I am on side with my party when we say there are fundamental problems that we have to see changed before we can vote for this bill.

Mr. Speaker, I have just heard the hon. member for Chambly say that he and his party would oppose such legislation. I am a little confused here and I would like him to tell me this: When he talks against a Canada-wide referendum and
May 19, 1992

Government Orders
says he would not vote for such a law, is he speaking for himself or on behalf of his party? I am quite puzzled.

Mr. Speaker, I will gladly answer my hon. colleague's question. Let me just quote an article from the April 29, 1992, edition of La Presse which says: "The NDP refuses to approve the plans for a referendum without first knowing what the wording of the question will be." In the same article, Ms. McLaughlin is also reported as saying, and I share her views on this: "Why put a bill forward if you do not know where you are going?" That is what I was saying. To those who would like to drive a wedge between Ms. McLaughlin and myself or to set us against each other, I will repeat what I said before: Cut the partisanship. This makes a lot of sense. Let us not forget it.
My point is that we would like to see this constitutional issue resolved. That is the basic issue. The way to resolve it is, especially at this time, for the native groups and the Prime Minister to come to an agreement. We in Quebec can hold our own referendum because they say the problem is with us. If that is the case, we will decide for ourselves.
Another thing, it is highly scornful for the people of Quebec and even the people of British Columbia and Alberta who are pretty well in the same boat.

Mr. Speaker, this has to be pursued. The member says that to justify his position he and his party are in favour of a referendum for Quebec but against a referendum for the rest of the country because if we have a referendum across the rest of the country we will somehow be scorning Quebec.
He quotes his leader and maybe I misunderstood. He spoke about mepris pour le Quebec, les Quebecois. "Mepris" is "scorn". I would like to know whether he is speaking on behalf of his leader when he says that he supports the principle of a referendum for the province of Quebec, yet he does not support the principle of a pan-Canadian referendum. If he does take this position, how can he square that circle? Surely the notion of a referendum in giving the chance to the people to have their say is a notion that is not exclusive to one part of the country but indeed is critical for all parts of the country. I would like him to square that circle because he and his leader are saying two different things.

I think I can say that pretty well, Mr. Speaker, in one minute. What we are saying essentially is that the provinces have decided that they would like to go the referendum route, certain provinces: British Columbia, I mentioned, which my colleague conveniently or perhaps inconveniently forgot. I mentioned Alberta and I also mentioned that perhaps even Manitoba would like to have hearings before a referendum comes out.
What I am saying is this. There is a timetable for Quebec to decide on federal offers and to decide on sovereignty. Let us get those federal offers up front and maybe a renewed Senate and maybe I hope self-government for aboriginal people. There may be a number of other things, including some administrative agreements between Quebec and Ottawa on power sharing.
Once that is done, let us vote on it. Do you know what, Mr. Speaker, we may as Quebecers not only save Canada but also save Canada $108 million. Maybe that is something that Liberals would not understand.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to participate this debate on Bill C-81 with some trepidation. When I was elected back in 1988, and prior to that, I formulated the opinion that as a member of Parliament I was elected first to represent my constituency; second, to make decisions that were in general good for Canada; and third, to make sure I understood those decisions and made on behalf of my constituents. Yet here I am in this House debating the idea of a referendum, something that in principle I have been not comfortable with in my view of Canada.
I look back in history at some of the referendums that have taken place. What I will do is go to a questionnaire that I did in my riding on the issue of the Constitution.
I mailed out some 55,000 questionnaires to my constituents. I asked them their views on the 28 different proposals that were put forth by the government on amending the Constitution. I received quite a number of responses. In those responses people were asked to indicate whether they were either strongly in favour, in favour, opposed, strongly opposed or had no opinion on the question.

Government Orders
On all 28 proposals I would say except for one, there was very strong support for 27 proposals and on the 28th it was 50/50. I put a 29th question in. That question was: Would you be prepared to compromise your position? If you got all those things you agreed with, would you accept all those things you did not agree with? I had a 75 per cent no vote, even though if I looked back at all the questions, I had an overwhelming yes vote.
I am talking about a referendum where I presume the question will be yes or no; do you agree with this, whatever that magic formula or equation is. I look at my constituents who all thought there were a bunch of good deals in there but they would vote no on the whole package. My concern is that I sense that as being very divisive.
We have heard reference in this House to other referendums that have taken place in this country. We can go back to the conscription referendum. There is the argument about was there concurrence in this country. It appears that the majority of those who voted clearly voted yes. However, there is a group saying in this House that there was a significant group who voted no and therefore that particular referendum should have been interpreted on a regional basis. There is an argument that there was a region upset because the balance of Canada overruled them.
What would be different if we had had it done in the reverse in the early forties? We would have had another chunk of Canada upset with the outcome even though they were in the majority because a minority supported it.
I stand here and say that I am not sure I am comfortable with referenda, but I also understand very clearly in my riding, as happened in the rest of Canada, that Canadians want to have an opportunity to input.
Although there have been quite a number of opportunities, I would like to quote a particular line from the Speech from the Throne: "You will be asked to approve enabling legislation to provide for greater participation of Canadian men and women in constitutional change".
I note that this particular bill is entitled "An act to provide for referendums on the Constitution of Canada". This referendum bill is a very specific bill that deals with a very specific subject. We are not talking about general legislation as it might apply to a whole series of questions that could be put to a national referendum.
Since it relates to this particular subject and a debate that many Canadians have wanted to participate in, in spite of my thoughts about the general thrust of a referendum, I plan on supporting this legislation.
Why would I go along with this process? First off, it is clear to me that the Constitution of Canada and the problems that are being caused by this never ending debate must come to an end. One way or another, this debate must end. Hopefully, it ends because we have the federal government, the 10 provincial governments, the two territorial governments, other interested parties, the aboriginal community and whoever else may be covered in this constitutional amendment. Hopefully we have a deal. If we have a deal there may not be a need for a referendum. Would that not be absolutely great? That is what this legislation provides for.
If we have a deal that is accepted across this country, then the government really has a choice of whether to hold a referendum. Personally speaking, if we have this deal across the country I would then argue that there is really no need for a referendum. Members of Parliament are elected to make decisions, therefore let us make them because we have this concurrence across the country.
If we did not have that concurrence, and we have had some debate in this House today about the need for a referendum, could you image what will happen in this country? There is going to be a referendum question in Quebec. There is going to be one in British Columbia and I believe there may be one in Saskatchewan. We will have three provinces for sure and there may be others that will hold a referendum.
If the other seven provincial governments decide in their wisdom that they do not need to hold a referendum but that ratification of the Constitution is dependent upon at least seven provincial governments in this country approving it, it seems to me that the federal government should have the ability to go to those seven provinces and say the other three are holding referendums to approve this package or not to approve this package, as the case may be. It seems to

me the federal government should have the right to consult with the other seven governments.
It is also possible that because of provincial legislation, the three governments that require a referendum will have one, but it could be the same question we put in the other seven provinces so that all Canadians in all 10 provinces and the territories are being asked to answer the same question. That would be an ideal situation. I guess that is part of the option available to us in this particular piece of legislation.
This referendum is not binding on the government. Should the bill pass and ultimately should the question be put to Canadians, it is not binding. Why not? I go back to the question I asked my constituents in which the majority very clearly said they agreed with the individual 28 proposals but objected to the 29th question which asked if they accept the whole package. It seems to me that in parts of this country, whether it is my particular riding east of Toronto or some riding in western or eastern Canada, if they should really get into a debate point and they vote no, even though they like the individual proposals save one, the federal government should certainly have the ability to interpret throughout the land the substance of the debate and then determine whether it agrees with the substance and then take its decision, which is what we were elected to do.
Over and above that, what happens in this referendum? Clearly, the legislation says that the vote must be taken 45 days after the question is approved by both the House of Commons and the Senate. There is a very clear time line on that. The point is that all members in this House will have an opportunity to fully participate in the preparation of the question and deciding whether the question is the right question to put to Canadians.
Between these two houses, the House of Commons and the Senate, I am sure we will come up with a question that Canadians can easily understand, not like some of the questions that we have heard asked in the past. We need to look at some of those questions in the past which have left a lot of doubt as to their actual meaning.
Government Orders
I can even go back to the last major provincial referendum that has certainly had an impact in Canada. The one held in Quebec basically argued the concept of sovereignty association. With all due respect, what did all that mean? I would say that was not a very clear question, at least not in my mind as an observer to that particular debate.
Is there fairness in the system that is being proposed by this bill? I think so. I would probably support some amendments. I may not put them myself, but there is some fairness in this legislation. It requires that three hours of time be given by national broadcasting networks to the question. Those on the yes side and those on the no side would have the time equally split. I am not sure why we would even put that in here.
Why would we force private networks to accept equally, free of charge, participation on this subject? We should not require the CTV, the Global network, the Ontario network or the CBC to give anybody any free time. They can sell it. If they cannot afford to buy the advertising time on television, then they should not have access to television.
There are some spending limits which are very appropriate such as the spending limits of $5,000 or else you have to form a referendum committee. If you form a referendum committee, you have to declare your sources of revenue over $250. It seems to me that that is very appropriate. Some would argue that may not be fair.
I go back again to that last election that I participated in in 1988. There was a group called the Council of Canadians. It started a campaign against free trade. Never did you see or hear how much money it spent or where it got its money from.
Because it did that kind of stuff, there was another group formed called the BCNI, the Business Council on National Issues, which spent money on promoting the yes side of the free trade agreement. I guess my point is whether you are on the yes side or the no side, those groups were able somehow to fund themselves and participate in the debate.
Should the same kind of debate occur this time, it will be compulsory, unlike it was then, for these groups to publicly identify themselves and to identify their sources of money if they spend more than $5,000. That is a degree of fairness that did not exist in 1988 and whether you were on the yes side of the free trade debate in 1988 or the no side, very clearly, it was very difficult to distinguish because not in every ad, not in every article was there a very clear indication of who

Government Orders
these groups and people were and who was paying all these gobs of money for whatever the viewpoint was.
This legislation is going to be very clear. It sets out that if you spend money, you are going to have to identify yourself. The committee that is organized on their behalf will have to do so. That is a very positive step.
The other rules that apply are those that relate to elections. You do not very often, at least in areas I travel, hear complaints about the fact that the elections were not fair, that there was cheating at the ballot box or there was unfair registration of candidates and all of those kind of accusations that may go on in other countries around the world.
At least in Canada the election system by and large is deemed to be a very fair and open process. The majority of the rules that apply to federal elections will apply to this particular debate. That is another degree of fairness that I do not have any problem with.
I have already mentioned the idea of donations and expenses, that these will have to be registered if they are more than $250. They must be reported to the returning officer. The committee that spends this money must have its accounts audited, not unlike a federal election. It must verify all expenses.
All of the surplus revenue either must be returned to the people who have donated it so there is no chance for a personal profit on somebody's part or must be given over to Her Majesty in right, I believe is the term used, so that nobody can personally pocket funds from this particular process.
I see that whole process lending more fairness to it all.
Further, there are differences in all parts of Canada and I do not think anybody would debate that. We come to the whole issue of who asked the question, who answers the question and on what basis.
Imagine the federal government putting out the question and one province deciding that it is not going to support this, rather, it is going to put the resources of its provincial government on to the no side of the campaign. I do not know why that would happen but for argument's sake it could happen.
Whether the legislation was there or not we cannot control provincial governments and their participation in the democratic process, nor do I want us to control that. We have to recognize that Canada is a federation in which there are provinces with specific jurisdictions in certain areas that we cannot interfere with.
When we talk about federal government spending versus provincial government spending, it is wise that this bill does not really say a lot about those two subjects because we have the controls, we have the ability to react if necessary. We also have the ability to go into a particular province if that province or that region of a province decides it does not like the way the process is going and interferes. I support that whole - heartedly.
There are other provinces that require some public hearings to to deal with any amending legislation and it seems to me that this process will not interfere with their hearings. I guess in theory it will not interfere if the province decides to hold hearings at the same time that the federal government is holding its referendum. In the media at least one might be overshadowed by the other.
One has to understand that in order to amend the constitution referendum, this House, the Senate, and at least seven provinces if not 10, depending on the exact amendments, must vote in their respective jurisdictions yes to the particular amendment that is being proposed.
When we have that specific amendment, whether there are hearings or whether there is a referendum or a plebiscite, we cannot lose sight of the fact that governments ultimately must vote on the issue.
The final point I would like to make is the issue of different kinds of governments that we have in this country and the problems that we have faced. We experienced them the last time we had a deal on the Constitution. There were elections held in some of the provinces between the time the accord was ratified by the various premiers and the Prime Minister and the three-year time frame.
Governments changed and in the wisdom of those governments the deal was cancelled. I find it unfortunate that kind of situation occurred but we have to understand that with the multiplicity of government types, the multiplicity of viewpoints that come from those governments, whether they be the socialist views of the Liberal and NDP opposite us or the Conserva-

tive view, there has to be some open option for the government to deal with this very important question.
It is because of the openness required and the many options that we face that I plan on supporting this particular referendum legislation even though in principle I do not think I was elected to deal with referenda. I was elected to make decisions.
Finally, I have heard the point about should we have regional requirements. Should there be a requirement that if a certain portion of Canada votes no and the rest votes yes that it cancels out? If we were in a unitary state one might argue that is a legitimate point of view. This bill is in a sense silent on that because it does not get to the specific question being asked.
When I look at the 185,000 people I represent, I want to know full well that the voice of my constituents is equal in stature to the voice of anyone else in this country.
That is why I am pleased to see this bill is silent on the particular issue of regional voting. When that question is ultimately put forward and when the future of this country is voted on, if it is voted on in a referendum, my constituents want to know that their voice is worth exactly the same as every other voice in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I followed what the hon. member said with great interest because I understand of course he does see the need for changes. Although he may not propose amendments to this particular bill, he would perhaps support a certain number of changes to it. In all frankness, I appreciate the fact that he made us aware of that today.
I would like to ask him this question. It comes from a study of referenda that was made by Michel David from Le Soleil in Quebec City. He said that there is a basic problem with a government which is unpopular hoping to get a mandate from a population which may not be able to differentiate between the question and the government that poses the question. Let me be precise in what I am trying to get at.
With a government that is as unpopular as this Conservative government is right now-it is at about 20 per cent popularity right now, but has been at 11
Government Orders
per cent-there is a great risk that people will vote against the messenger or will vote against specific questions in this referendum mainly because they do not like Brian Mulroney. They do not trust Brian Mulroney; they do not want to see him in office for another term. They would vote against this because Brian Mulroney is unpopular.
Does the hon. member on the government side recognize this problem of shooting the messenger and perhaps killing Quebec and Canada as well? I ask for the same measure of frankness as I have just heard. If he does recognize that, what would he suggest could be done to avoid this possibility?
In a referendum question so that we could have a consensus, what would be a question in a referendum across Canada that could rally everybody in a yes or no response?

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the comment about the possibility of people shooting the messenger.
All I would indicate in the first case is that in my constituency when people go to the ballot box they are prepared to make an educated vote. They did so in the last election and I believe they will do so in the future.
Having said that, using the logic of the hon. member, I do not know why Bob Rae's government continues to do all the things it does because it is certainly very unpopular. The New Democrats in Ontario believe the myth that what they are doing is in fact good for the people of Ontario. They are entitled to that view.

Mr. Speaker, one of the amendments that has been proposed by a number of people on this side has been to modify the wording in the current proposed referendum legislation. Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the question and I understand the direction from which it comes.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have this opportunity to speak to this bill because Parliament has been expecting for a long time the introduction of a bill like Bill C-81.
It is appropriate to recall the story about someone who is asked whether he wants to hear the good news first or the bad news first. I think we had better start with the good news and that is the government has agreed, at long last, through this bill C-81, to give itself the means of consulting the people on amendments to the Constitution of Canada.
I do not have to remind you, Mr. Speaker, that the Leader of the Opposition mentioned, as early as April 1991, the importance in the present round of constitutional negotiations of the possibility, as a last recourse, of consulting the people on proposed amendments to the Constitution.
In the Beaudoin-Edwards committee, our party stressed the importance of having within the Canadian constitutional arsenal the capacity of going to the people. That is why we, Liberal members, joined with other members of the House and the Senate in this joint parliamentary committee to pass unanimously a recommendation to the conservative government, urging it to pass a bill permitting it to go to the people.
It is clear, that if we allow that the people of a province, Quebec in particular, be given the opportunity to express their opinion on their constitutional future, it ensues that we are perfectly justified to give Canadians in other provinces an opportunity to express their views on their constitutional future.
Government Orders
Holding a referendum is a very democratic process. In our democratic system, this might be the most logical, natural and desirable course of action. We in the Official Opposition can only be pleased to see, at last, the government assume its responsibilities and introduce a bill to hold, if necessary, a referendum on constitutional proposals that could be accepted by all provinces and the Canadian government, or by some provinces and the Canadian government.
Now for the bad news, as the story goes. There are frightful shortcomings in this legislation that could totally void even the most democratic aspects of this consultation of the people.
How can the Conservative government do this amazing trick, provide on the one hand for a very democratic means of going to the people and, on the other hand, present such an anti-democratic bill? It is clear that we are going to try and convince the government of amending its bill, that we are going to do everything in our power to pressure the government into amending this bill.
First, we believe that there should be a spending limit. The bill does not limit spendings by either side of the referendum question. Finally, it does not even provide for an umbrella, as was the case with the referendum held in Quebec in 1980. Canadians support the idea of a referendum. I believe that the polls show clearly that a majority of Canadians would like to be consulted at this particular time on the constitutional issue. But, as much as they want to be consulted, they also want this to be done on an equitable basis. The bill, which does not provide for umbrella committees and which does not include any reasonable spending limits, is severely lacking in this regard. This could result in a process which might not be as democratic as it should be.
Canadians do not want the outcome of the exercise to be fixed. They want a well-deserved result.lt seems essential to us, if we want to convince Quebecers that they should remain part of Canada, that this exercise be credible, acceptable and not flawed from a procedural point of view. There is no point for the minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs, to try to convince the provinces to accept a valid proposal to solve the constitutional deadlock and tell Quebecers "here is what we are willing to offer, which is much better than an independent Quebec", if this exercise is to be thwarted by a steamroller of a referendum which literally buys Quebecers and which deprives them of a logical, rational and fair debate. We, the Liberals, are

Government Orders
not afraid of holding an equitable referendum in Quebec, based on concrete and specific proposals that are favourable to Quebecers. Quebecers do not need to be bought by Mulroney's big dollars to give their support to Canada. What concerns us is the approach undertaken now with this bill, which is totally unacceptable in the circumstances.
We also think that in the present context, given our past experiences with referenda, it would be important to include a small clause clearly stipulating that the government will be guided by the results of the referendum, not only by a majority that it hopes to get for all of Canada, but also by a majority that it will want to obtain in each of the main regions of the country, so that Quebecers, when they participate in this referendum, will know that they are not buried by the majority vote of the Canadian population, but that they will also have what we call the "double majority", that they will also have in Quebec, we hope, a majority that will accept the constitutional proposal.
It seems to us that it is absolutely essential at this time to be very up front with the population of Quebec and say that the overwhelming majority of Canadians will not force a constitutional change upon them. With this referendum, we will recognize at the outset that it will not only be necessary to get a majority throughout the country, but also a majority in Quebec as well as in each of the other large regions of Canada, so that this consultation process take into account the legitimate ambitions of each of the large regions of our country.
A third change we are advocating deals with the wording of the question. A spokesperson said earlier, and justly so, that the Canadian Prime Minister no longer has the credibility to hold a Canada-wide referendum alone and win the support of all Canadians. It seems obvious that those who believe in Canada among the three major national parties- meaning the government, namely the Conservative Party, the Official Opposition, namely the Liberal Party, and the New Democratic Party, three of the best known members of which are provincial premiers-should all get together to draft the question to be put to the people of Canada.
Hear. Hear.

We can obviously not rely solely on the discretion of the Prime Minister. He has neither the credibility nor the support at this point in time to carry the constitutional issue through on his own.
Canada's interest transcends political parties. It is in that context that the Leader of the Opposition has been talking for over a year now about the need for co-operation between the three major national parties in order to resolve the constitutional crisis.
To my great regret, I must say that, unfortunately, opposition parties were not consulted at all on this bill. We have been called to the office of the government House leader only to be told: "Here is what it will be." There was no consultation, only a briefing.
Under the circumstances, we deeply deplore this move on the part of government. If this is any indication of what it has in store for the weeks to come, it tells you this is scary, very scary, because we feel that the interest of Canada should obviously take precedence over that of political parties. It seems to me that the Prime Minister of Canada is more concerned by his self-interest and his political survival than by the best interest of this country when he brings forward a bill such as this one.
I think that the points made about the Canadian Charter of Rights are totally preposterous and superfluous. I will refer to an article by Michel Auger published on May 16 in Le Journal de Montreal which state, regarding this argument: "Prime Minister Mul-roney said on Thursday that the government would have gladly used the Quebec model, with two umbrella committees, for its own referendum on the Constitution, but the Charter prevents it."
The Lortie commission looked into the matter. I must remind my hon. colleagues that this commission worked for two years and made very specific recommendations based on legal opinions paid for by the Conservative government which state clearly that it is possible to limit expenses incurred by a third party for an election or by umbrella committees for a referendum without contravening the charter.
May 19, 1992

I would suggest that the Prime Minister and the government House leader refer to the Lortie report to make sure that the legal opinions provided by the lawyer they have paid to assist the Lortie commission are not ignored. It seems obvious to me that the charter clearly says that the citizens have rights, but it also says in its first section that freedoms are not absolute and can be subject to such reasonable limits as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society.
During the weekend, Professor Mendes of the University of Western Ontario law school, faxed me his legal opinion in which he explained in great detail how the charter can limit certain expenses in the case of a referendum legislation. He referred particularly to the recent decision of Justice Sopinka in the Queen v. Butler. I will read this paragraph of his legal opinion:

I would suggest that the appropriate standard is that laid down by Justice Sopinka in the R v. Butler decision that Parliament is entitled to have "a reasonable apprehension of harm" resulting from the dangers which the legislation is attempting to avoid.
"It would be quite easy for the government to have proved in an appeal from Justice Medhurst's decision"- and this is the decision that was rendered in Alberta at the time of the 1984 election-that the Conservative government did not want to appeal. It should have appealed. The chief electoral officer asked the government to appeal and it never wanted to appeal.
This decision is quite clear, that "there is a reasonable apprehension of harm resulting from unlimited spending during elections or referendums".
Professor Mendes concludes by saying:
Perhaps the reasons why the government did not appeal Justice Medhurst's decision and why they do not wish to put spending limits in any referendum legislation have nothing to do with the Charter of Rights and Freedoms or with law at all.

In a nutshell, Mr. Speaker, those are the comments that I wanted to make at this point. It seems obvious to me that this bill, while it is desirable in itself, will have to be seriously amended if it wants to get the attention and the credibility that it needs.
Private Members' Business
I note that the member for Edmonton-Southwest spoke earlier in this House. He reminded quite appropriately that the parliamentary committee he co-chaired with Senator Beaudoin specifically recommended to the government of Canada, should it want to get a consensus on constitutional amendments or should it fail to agree with the 10 provincial governments, to submit to the people a constitutional agreement which could be supported by at least a majority of the provinces representing more than 50 per cent of the Canadian population.
It seems to me that this last resort approach of consulting the population to tell us whether or not our constitutional proposal is valid and acceptable and in the best interests of Canada is something that must be done, but it must be done properly, with very strict rules of election spending limits and also with umbrella committees for the yes side and the no side.
Observers will recognize that referendum legislations is historically common.
One was submitted to the Parliament of London to determine whether or not England should join the Common Market. On the yes side was a major group composed of all sorts of people and of all political allegiances. The same can be said for the no side. Now, the fact that the representatives from the Bloc Quebecois and the Reform Party -
