That, in the opinion of this House, the government should consider the advisability of introducing legislation to enable mothers with terminally ill children to take leave from their employment in order to care for such children.

Private Members' Business
He said: Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak in favour of this motion finally .It is a private member's motion that I have had in the hopper, so to speak, for a long time, I believe going back as far as 1989. The way in which Private Members' Business works here, in order for something to be debated, and perhaps even voted on, one has first of all to win the lottery by which we select those bills and motions that will come before the House.
In the last draw I was selected and this is the motion which I have chosen to bring forward. I say that because I want the House to know that I have been working on this issue for some time. I raised it in the House before in the context of Standing Order 21 and was somewhat disappointed when I learned that this motion had not been selected as a votable item.
The committee makes its own judgments about this and I am not here to dispute that, but I am told that one of the reasons the committee employed for not selecting it as a votable item was that it might have been in contravention of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. The reason for that is that in the motion I singled out mothers with terminally ill children as people who should be provided with some legislative protection vis-a-vis taking leave from their employment in order to care for such children.
There are some things which are obviously contrary to the charter and there are other things which are arguable. I do not think the committee or the House, for that matter, should prejudge in this case whether singling out mothers is something that goes against the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. If that were the case then I suppose the family allowance ought to be brought into disrepute because of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms in that it singles out mothers.
I do not think it should be beyond the legislative purview of the House of Commons to designate a benefit for mothers. On those grounds it is unfortunate that this is the reasoning that was employed.
Having said that, it probably would have been better if I had said in my motion legislation enabling parents or one parent or something like that. I acknowledge that. However, to have denied the House the opportunity to vote on this for that reason is at least debatable. The
House can vote on this. Those members who are in the House this afternoon can either vote on it or simply allow it go to committee and pass it.
What we have in this motion is an attempt to deal with the needs of a very small but significant group of people: those families stricken with what I think is the ultimate nightmare for any family or for any parent or parents, that is having to deal with a terminal illness, for instance cancer having inflicted itself upon one of their children.
The success rate in curing cancer is going up and up. We see that and everyone rejoices in it, so the group that I am talking about in the sense of children actually dying is getting smaller.
In the sense of families who are dealing with a process that has a successful outcome, we are still talking about a group the numbers of which are holding and perhaps expanding. Even with those families whose children are successfully cured of cancer or in beating cancer, there is an entire treatment and healing process they have to go through that can be very, very hard on families, particularly when we consider the number of double income families of necessity in the country today. It seems to me that we should not add misery upon tragedy by putting at least one parent in the situation of having to forgo the income which is necessary to their economic integrity at the same time as he or she is being attacked by fate or whatever you want to call it when one of their children is so seriously ill.
That is the object of this motion. I have written to ministers about this over the last few years. At first I would simply get answers which, to sum up, were basically that this would set a precedent that the government was not willing to live with because there might be others who wanted to take leave from work in order to care for an elderly parent or for a spouse or whatever.
Of course, my contention with the government was yes, I understand all those needs but what I am trying to make the case for then and now is that this is a special group of people who need a special form of attention by the government. I still think that is the case. If the government wants to look at other ways through our health care system or whatever mechanism we want to devise for enabling and/or helping out or even helping to recognize those many Canadians who do all of us a service by staying at home to look after sick or disabled
May 19, 1992

relatives, that is something the government should do. I am not arguing against that.
I have come across constituents when I have been canvassing either at election time or otherwise when people have complained to me that they are staying at home to look after a relative and get absolutely no recognition, economic or otherwise, for doing it. However, if they farmed out that person to the neighbour next door, they would be able to claim something for doing that.
This is a loophole, if you like, in our entire system; a loophole by which the kind of care motivated by family connection is not taken into account. That is a larger question and I do not think the fate of this particular motion should hinge on what people think of how we address that larger question because here we are talking about a very specific need.
Proposals have been made, and I refer in particular to a proposal for what is called a "caretaker allowance" for the families of children with cancer. The idea of a caretaker allowance has been put forward by the Candle-lighters Childhood Cancer Foundation Canada, the acronym of which is CCCFC. It is a national parent support group for families with children suffering from cancer and represents about 30 family support groups across Canada.
Although obviously that is a small number of people, nevertheless it is probably larger than any of us here care to think about. Unless we come up to them face to face in our own lives, we tend to be blithely unconscious of just what other people are experiencing or suffering.
This proposal has been made on a number of occasions. What I am trying to do through this motion is give Parliament an opportunity to cause the government to focus on this issue. I can chip away at the mountain, and other members might want to do so as well from time to time on issues like this, but if the House of Commons were today, because today is the only opportunity it is going to have for a long, long time to come to pass this motion-it's only a motion, it would not go into law or anything-the government would have to presumably take into account the fact that it has been instructed by the House of Commons to deal with this issue. It is
Private Members' Business
something that all of us could then hold the government to account for.
We could say there was a motion passed in the House of Commons instructing the government to deal with this problem. It would create a situation in which much more progress would be made on this issue and in a much swifter way.
That is my goal here today. I hope that other members might take the opportunity to speak to this, to support the motion and have it go through. Then the government would have to focus on this particular issue.
I would like to quote, if I might, from the proposal by the Candlelighters Foundation because I think they say it better than I could. They say:
The treatment of childhood cancer has improved dramatically over the last 20 years due to co-ordinated efforts internationally. Whereas in the 1960s the overall long term survival of any type and stage of childhood cancer was less than 20 per cent, today it is in the 65 -70 per cent range and hopefully will be in the 80 -85 per cent range in the next ten years.
The survival of children with cancer has improved because of the increasing use of intensive chemotherapy. This trend is likely to continue with the advent of new treatment modalities known as growth factors and oncogenes as well as the proliferation of new chemotherapeutic agents.
However this approach has several ramifications. More intensive therapy causes more serious side effects resulting in lengthier hospital admissions and home convalescence. Hospital admissions for childhood cancer can range from a few weeks to several months. Length of treatment of childhood cancer, depending on the type, range from six months to three years and longer if there are relapses.
Because of the increasing health costs and the focus in paediatrics to maintain the parents as primary care givers the families have assumed more and more responsibility to care for children at home, requiring complex treatment such as tube feedings, total parenteral nutrition, central line care, pain pumps, ostomy care and a myriad of other procedures.
With most families -
This is a point I made earlier, Mr. Speaker:
- being double income earners, of necessity, and with the intensive nature of treatment and outpatient management, parents must take lengthy absences from work, with usually one parent, the mother, taking an indefinite leave of absence or actually quitting her job. Very seldom do they qualify for unemployment sick benefits, as they must indicate they are under extreme emotional stress.
In other words, on top of having this, they have to jump through a whole bunch of bureaucratic and medical hoops themselves, which I think is totally uncalled for in the situation. Going back to the proposal:

Private Members' Business
Disability insurance also requires consultation to a psychiatrist to prove that the applicant is indeed suffering severe emotional stress due to his/her child's illness. This type of absence is incorporated into their employment record and may unduly influence employers' attitudes. Many times social workers have had to lobby Members of Parliament who have interceded on a family's behalf. It is only then, with publicity, that the unemployment benefits have been approved.
I am aware of a few situations like that and I am sure other members here are as well. We should not have to do that. People should not have to go through that kind of hassle at that particularly difficult time in their lives. There should be a mechanism, which is exactly what this motion calls for, to provide for people in that kind of situation.
Going back again to the Candlelighters Foundation proposal:
This issue is universal to all families who have children with cancer. We cannot expect families to assume the massive burden of care with little in the way of financial assistance, if a family is to survive the devastation of cancer.
The objective of the CCCFC is a caretaker allowance for the parent who must care for the child which has cancer whether in hospital or at home. It is not just a matter of being at home but sometimes it is the case of being at the hospital day after day and night after night.
They would like the allowance to be equivalent to the unemployment insurance illness benefit maximum payment. They feel this type of benefit should be by application and should begin within four weeks of diagnosis, continue until the child is off treatment, and resume if a relapse occurs.
Obviously they feel this would have to be supported by documentation from the child's physician. It is not the sort of thing that would be open to fraud in any way at all I am sure. Any worries people might have in that regard are unfounded.
We do have such a thing as special illness benefits under the current unemployment insurance benefits for those who are unable to work because of an illness, quarantine, pregnancy, or the adoption of a child. It is not as if we do not have these kinds of mechanisms within existing legislation.
Surely it is not beyond the wit, wisdom and wiles of the Canadian Parliament and the government with its resources to come up with a mechanism that would enable us to address the needs of this particular group.
As I say, in the instances of pregnancy and adoption a parent can claim special benefits to stay home to care for a child. Surely to goodness they should be able to do that in these circumstances.
If we had such a mechanism, the family would be able to continue to provide for regular living expenses as well as the additional costs that inevitably arise because of the illness of the child. These additional requirements, for instance, could include expensive medication, babysitting, perhaps for other children in the family, transportation to and from the hospital, hospital parking fees, meals, extra clothing because of weight loss or gain due to medication, special equipment for the care of the sick child, homemakers, home nursing. There are all kinds of expenses which are not necessarily covered by medicare.
All we are suggesting is that in this circumstance the people at least not be deprived of the income to which they are normally accustomed, although even the maximum payment under UIC might in many cases be less than what people would make if they stayed at their job. What is being suggested in this proposal is that people not be deprived entirely of one of the two incomes they are dependent on in this particularly difficult economic and emotional situation.
This is the proposal I am placing before the House. I would certainly be prepared to make copies of this proposal and some of the attached information and rationale available for members who may be interested in this. I hope that this afternoon we could actually do something here. Often we spend a lot of time here not feeling we are accomplishing a great deal. Surely we could agree among ourselves today, particularly given that it is a motion and not legislation.
It does not even go to a committee. All it has to do is pass this House in the next 40 minutes and it will be there on the record for the duration of this Parliament and for Parliaments to come, until such time as the government deals with this issue. It is an instruction by the House of Commons to the government, take heed, pay attention, look at the needs of this special group and do something about it.

Mr. Speaker, it is always a great pleasure to take part in such a debate.

One of the most significant labour trends in our country has been the increase in the number of working mothers. It is estimated that by the year 2000 women will account for nearly one-half of all Canadian workers.
Recognition of the family responsibilities of workers has prompted family-leave policies in the private sector, in collective bargaining agreements and provincial and federal legislation.
A comment that I would like to make about the hon. member's motion in connection with the necessity for women to take leave to care for a terminally ill child would be to add the word "father" along with mother as men are now taking on additional family responsibilities.
I was particularly impressed with the member's arguments about the need for us to be more open to suggestions like this, and he is quite correct. This motion has come up in Parliament on a number of occasions and I did take part in other debates. However, I would like to put the motion, if I might, in the context of the entire labour force and see how this suggestion fits in with it.
Under the labour force development strategy of Bill C-21 which became law, the member was here, in November 1990, maternity benefits were improved at an annual cost of $450 million. These benefits, as he pointed out in a cursory way, included 15 weeks of maternity benefits available to natural and adoptive parents, either mother or father, or shared between them. Parents are eligible for an additional five weeks in parental benefits if the child is ill. An additional five weeks was included primarily at the insistence of adoptive parents who wished more bonding time with their new child.
To be eligible for the additional five weeks, the child must be six months or older at the time of placement or when the child comes home. The illness of the child would have to be certified by a doctor, but I would point out that it can be of a physical, psychological or emotion-
Private Members' Business
al nature. This leaves quite a broad spectrum for a doctor to make a pronouncement on. This would naturally require an extra period of parental care.
Departmental officials claim that 90 per cent of adoptive parents will qualify for the additional five weeks, 15 weeks sickness benefits. Any contributor to the UIC plan is eligible to claim sickness benefits. More than one type of benefit can be claimed; that is, maternity, parental and sickness. Within the claim period, one can claim up to 30 weeks.
If we look at these points in order, we can understand why the Employment Standards Act as a provincial statute is inconsistent with the UIC act. Labour standards vary from province to province. While the federal government can set examples, as in the case of reasonably progressive measures like maternity and parental benefits, it cannot force the provinces to pass similar legislation.
The fact that Ontario parents are eligible for a minimum, I repeat a minimum, of leave of six weeks is not the fault of the federal law. It is a failing, in my opinion, of Queen's Park; that is to say, it is a failing in the provincial legislation.
My party submitted amendments to Bill C-21 which would increase parental benefits for natural and adoptive parents from 10 to 15 weeks, regardless of child illness, and eliminate the maximum benefits of 30 weeks when maternity, parental and sickness benefits are combined.
It has always been our commitment to improve the maternity and parental leave provisions of the unemployment fund so that eligibility guidelines and benefits can better reflect the changing needs of Canadian society.
Some time ago a report on social trends reported that a poll taken from among a cross-section of women indicated, and I am quoting him directly, "a guilt so intense it has put many working mothers in a winding sheet of anxiety", the guilt being of course the fact that women are working outside the home.
One might well imagine how intensified that guilt is when a child is sick, or worse when a child is terminally ill. This is what the hon. member is talking about.

May 19, 1992
Private Members' Business
Working outside the home has became a financial necessity for many. Others often enjoy the satisfaction of a family and a career at the same time. This is their choice and I would surely not have any quarrel with it as I have two daughters who are doing that just at this moment.
Statistic Canada says that the picture of the household with dad at work and mom at home with the children is no longer a statistic. Fully 70 per cent of families with children under 16 in 1990 had mothers in the work force. Sixty-eight per cent of families with children under school age had a working mom. The Vanier Institute of the Family in Ottawa showed that the so-called family wage, a salary that could support a man, a wife and children, has largely disappeared in spite of the fact that many more women have entered the work force. In fact, if women stopped working, the number of low income families would rise by an estimated 62 per cent, according to the institute.
Canadians still crave the stability of a family rather than material goods. Goldfarb Consultants has also done some research tracking social trends nation-wide since 1980. About 30 per cent of parents polled declared categorically that they feel they do not spend enough time with their children. Social workers and counsellors often remark that during the counselling sessions with mothers of young children, the mothers comment about the torture they feel to do their best at a job and parenting at the same time. It is never easy for a young mother to go out and do a full day's work and come home and still be faced with all the chores she has to do at home, including of course spending time with her very precious children.
At the annual conference of First Ministers held in Ottawa in November 1989, the Government of Canada submissioned to the talks the necessity to support the family. Here is a text of the opening paragraph:
In its capacity as legislator, the Government of Canada has an important role in regulating work practices and providing labour market programs to support the efforts of individuals to balance work and family responsibilities.
Through his motion, the hon. member has raised a most valid concern which must be addressed at the federal level if we are to follow through with a plan to really support the efforts of individuals to "balance work and family responsibilities".
I do have a few nagging questions. I wonder, if this motion was passed, would this leave of a parent, mother or father, be paid leave? Would it be paid through the UIC? Would there be benefits from there? Would there be a cap on the amount of time that the parent could spend with the child that is terminally ill?
I am very open to this type of suggestion, as is my party. If we could have some suggestions or information on it, I believe this is the type of thing toward which we should be advancing as we deal with the social problems and the social opportunities of this day.
I would encourage the hon. member to continue in his quest to have this motion passed. With a little more information, it could be supported by members on our side.

Mr. Speaker, on a point of order, the member's concerns are met with the motion.
The motion simply instructs the government to come up with a proposal to do this. It would be up to the people in his own party to come forward with a proposal. It is not a question of having to deal with the details today. It is simply a question of having the House instruct the government to come back to the House at some future date with a proposal that would deal with the concerns that the member has raised.

Mr. Speaker, I was deeply touched by the motion from my colleague, the hon. member for Winnipeg Transcona, to enable mothers with terminally-ill children to take leave from their employment in order to care for such children.
We know that there are more and more women in the labour force. Being a mother myself, as my colleagues know -not a young mother, but a recent mother -I realize to what extent the responsibilities of caring for the children fall on the mothers, for the most part. I do not mean to belittle in any way the responsibilities fathers might assume, but it is a fact that the role of mothers is extremely important.
When children are sick, the role of the parents-I will use the plural, because I know that both mother and father have a very important role to play-becomes parts of the treatment and the cure. On top of chemical, physiological or medical treatments, you also have the moral, psychological, emotional and physical support that parents can provide to a child who has to undergo treatment, who must experience extremely stressful and
May 19, 1992

painful circumstances that have normally no part in childhood.
I was touched by the motion. Obviously our government could explore the possibility of amending labour laws or regulations to deal with situations like the one described, situations with are extreme and exceptional.
Clearly, as another member was saying a while ago, there are details to iron out. For example, would the leave be covered by unemployment insurance? Should there be a time limit for the payments, if payments are made? For the time being, we are only debating the principle of the thing, and I think it has merit, especially since we keep repeating that families make the social fabric, and that a healthy society starts with healthy families.
I wish to support this motion but add that the role of the father could be substituted for the role of the mother when the circumstances require it, but it is true that statistically it is more often the mother than the father who is involved.

Mr. Bill Kempling (Parliamentary Secretary to President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State
(Finance)): Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise today to make a few remarks with respect to Motion M-72 which proposes that the government should consider the advisability of introducing legislation to enable mothers with terminally ill children to take leave from their employment in order to care for such children.
One can certainly sympathize with the intent of the motion. However, my hon. friend has not taken into account the fact that by limiting the leave to mothers of terminally ill children, this motion is discriminatory. I have heard his remarks that explain that this could be amended down the road. There are also those who say that it contravenes the Charter of Rights and they ask about the fathers, step-parents and guardians of terminally ill children.
The motion is also vague in its lack of definition of a child. For instance, at what stage does a person cease to be a child? Is the standard one of chronology or one of dependency?
Private Members' Business
As well, there is no indication of criteria for determining the point at which an illness becomes terminal and what length of time is envisaged with regard to leave granted.
Surely these critical elements might introduce an emotion that has far-reaching repercussions.
We have also not been advised as to what obligations will be imposed on employers and to what extent they will be required to continue an assortment of benefits including seniority, health care, pension coverage and while the employee is on leave.
While I appreciate the spirit in which the motion is being tabled, I believe the hon. member did not quite take into account all the complexities and ramifications that any legislation in this domain will have incorporated.
This government has an ongoing commitment to harmonize the work and the family life of Canadians. Over the past few decades we have seen a profound change in attitudes in this increasingly important area. These changes have taken place as the nature and the composition of the work force have evolved.
Only a few statistics have been cited to show how dramatic the changes have been. In 1965, 65 per cent of all Canadian families were what has customarily been thought of as traditional families; that is, there is only one wage earner.
Ten years later this proportion was cut in half and by 1981 only 16 per cent of all families in Canada had the husband as the sole bread-winner. The result of the 1991 census will probably underscore that trend.
There have been other equally significant changes. The percentage of persons in the population over 65 is going up sharply. More and more working men and women are carrying for elderly parents or persons with disabilities. Men are increasingly sharing the care of the children.
Given these labour markets and attitudinal shifts, we have also needed to alter the manner in which we conceive of the relationship between work and family and even with one another.
These are important developments and actions must be taken.

May 19, 1992
Private Members' Business
What we actually do to integrate these two spheres of life needs to be considered. As well, we must consider all circumstances.
I hope my hon. friend appreciates that no single method is suitable for all work places. Initiatives will vary by both individuals and by work sites. Canadian businesses are showing increasing willingness to experiment to try whatever they believe is reasonable and practical to accommodate the needs of their employees.
This kind of progress calls for flexibility.
I would also like to point out that a wide variety of measures has already been introduced by employers and unions across the country. In many instances they have exceeded legislative minimum standards because of their growing recognition that the evolving nature of the work place plus the changing demographics necessitate resourceful measures which will come out in harmony rather than in disruption.
I can attest to this happening right in this very House where several years ago when I was the Whip of our party we were in the opposition. We had a member in the government party who had a child who was terminally ill. Because the balance in the House was rather close, he was unable to get permission to leave the House to go and spend any amount of time with his terminally ill child.
I arranged for a pair for him on a permanent basis so that he was able to be with the child in the last few months of its life. These sorts of things go on with employers across the country.
Computerized information is now available in many areas on community based facilities for children and the elderly as well as on support services available in the work place. There are subsidies available to sustain these ventures and many employers have introduced supplementary benefit plans and family supportive relocation policies.
Work on family initiatives requires planning and financial commitments. Some initiatives cost less than others and more are acceptable to a greater number of organizations. These include, for example, modification to benefit plans to cover elderly dependents.
I do not believe that the member, in proposing his motion, has considered how many variables are involved in the reconciliation of work and family life. This government is facilitating the process by working closely with labour and management as well as with the provincial and territorial jurisdictions.
Many highly beneficial adjustments have already taken place and the response from employers and employees has been positive. For instance, working hours have been rearranged to accommodate the new realities of the two-income family. Flexible working hours and options to work out of the home have already made great strides to meet family related needs of workers.
Balancing work and family responsibilities is also increasingly regarded as critical to the Canadian economy and the achievement of economic equality for women. Employers and labour organizations in steadily increasing numbers are recognizing the need to adapt the workplace to meet the changing needs of the work force.
I trust my hon. friend will appreciate from these remarks that considerable work has already been done to assist families to look after pressing personal needs. There is also a need to reconcile all these enterprising measures with the resources that are available. While the proposal that mothers with terminally ill children should be able to take leave from their employment in order to care for those children is both commendable and compassionate, I believe it is clear that any step in that singular direction is a piecemeal approach and is only one small part of balancing working and family responsibilities.

Mr. Speaker, on a point of order. Perhaps the House should be reminded that what we are debating here is a motion, not a bill. It is a motion calling for legislation that would embody all the flexibilities and variables and everything else the member just talked about.
We are simply talking about a motion here and I think the House should keep that in mind. A bill could be criticized for not doing all the things the member criticized this motion for. A motion is simply a motion that would instruct the government to come up with the legislation that would meet all the concerns the member has so ably itemized.
May 19, 1992

speakeroldname: Mr. Murray Cardiff (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Agriculture):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Agriculture
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise to respond to Motion M-72, which proposes that the government should consider the advisability of introducing legislation to enable mothers with terminally ill children to take leave from their employment in order to care for such children.
There is no question in my mind that this motion was bom out of compassionate motives, but unfortunately it does not take into account a number of very important considerations.
The hon. member should know that restricting this kind of leave to women is discriminatory or could be discriminatory toward male parents and therefore it could be a violation of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
Provincial and territorial ministers of labour met recently with the federal Minister of Labour to discuss, among other things, the whole issue of balancing work and family responsibilities. Each jurisdiction is developing policies and practices that will apply to all workers who have responsibility for children, spouses and elderly parents.
Labour Canada has already taken a number of significant steps to address the challenges intrinsic to a changing work force and shifting family priorities.
For instance, over the last 18 months Labour Canada has hosted three regional seminars on balancing work and family responsibilities.
As well, through the Workplace Equality Fund, WEF, Labour Canada supports projects aimed at ensuring equality for women in the work place. This fund gives
Private Members' Business
priority to projects involving labour management partnerships and to those focusing on the integration of work and family responsibilities.
Increasing numbers of employers are getting together with unions and employers to consult and co-operate in reaching an accord on family and work related issues. There is a growing recognition of the need for family-responsive work places that will act decisively as the labour force participation rate for women continues to grow and as elder care needs become increasingly important. This is particularly pertinent in the context of the apparent trend among Canadian workers to favour flexibility and choice in their lives.
One initiative involves increased work and family integration through work place support for workers with dependants. For example, some companies offer subsidies for respite care. This arrangement enables employees to return to work while care-giving responsibilities are assigned to health care professionals.
Other organizations have established on-sight or near-sight child care centres and still other companies have extended their employees dependant care coverage to include health and dental expenses for the employee's parents. Recently, the Bank of Montreal, recognizing that already two out of every five Canadians over age 30 provide some form of care for elderly relatives, began an elder care program. It offers employees counselling and assistance in dealing with older dependants. It seems likely that with the Canadian population aging, more and more workers will want to have benefits of this kind.
I believe that this kind of enlightened action, which benefits employees and employers alike, demonstrates clearly that legislation is not the only approach to family related issues that are felt in the workplace. We frequently underestimate the degree to which management and labour can sit down and co-operate on matters that affect both productivity and workplace harmony. This kind of collaboration can have a favourable impact on a company's over-all ability to compete and prosper for the benefit of all concerned.
While the bargaining table may be one area where problems or misunderstandings can be resolved, more often than not common sense and good will can form the basis of co-operation and partnership that will remove the obstacles toward accord and mutual trust.

May 19, 1992
Private Members' Business
Even with the difficult economic circumstances we face today, I believe it is possible for the work place partners to give a high priority to matters concerned with the reconciliation of work and family responsibilities. The progressive initiatives that have been implemented and perpetuated by far-sighted companies in the collaboration with responsible unions mirrors a more flexible and considerate perspective.
Recent research confirms these observations. It has been demonstrated that employers who offer family-responsive benefits to their employees find these benefits to be effective ways of recruiting and keeping competent workers. These factors also have been found to weigh heavily against stress and absenteeism in the work place. Improved morale has resulted and the over-all efficiency of the worker has also been enhanced in the process.
I believe hon. members are aware that the federal government continues to act as a catalyst, moving employers and employees closer together in the pursuit of solutions to work place and family questions. We know that an unhappy work force is less productive, less motivated and less lucky to make adjustments to the rapid technological changes taking place in the new world economic order.
All governments must continue to play a significant part in promoting partnership between employer and employee. We must encourage the expression of good will and common sense as we establish a more altruistic and amicable atmosphere, one within which we can make substantial progress in improving the lot of the worker while also addressing the viability of our economy.
Under the circumstances, in addition to the fact that the motion excludes fathers, step-parents and guardians, I am not prepared to support it at this time because there are already substantial innovations being undertaken to deal with work and family responsibilities. These initiatives are proceeding in an ongoing and effective manner.
The thought is good but I believe, as I have said earlier, we are addressing those issues on an ongoing basis and for that reason, I do not feel that I can support the motion.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ken James (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Labour):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I also want to respond to Motion M-72 proposed by my colleague across the way. I know he introduced this motion and put it in the hopper, as he said, a good long time ago because of his great interest in this very important area.
It proposes that the government, as he said earlier, should introduce legislation to enable mothers with terminally ill children to take leave from their employment to care for the children.
Previous speakers have indicated how responsive they are, and I think my hon. friend from Winnipeg knows that this government's response has been changing to the needs of the work force. As well, ample documentation was provided as to the manner in which companies and employees are collaborating to arrive at harmonious decisions affecting the reconciliation of work and family responsibilities. Certainly all are to be lauded for the amount of work that is going on in collective agreements and in co-operation between employer and employees.
I am sure all members realize that balancing work and family is increasingly recognized as being critical to the Canadian economy and to the achievement of equality for women especially. Employers and labour organizations acknowledge the need to adapt the work place to meet the changing needs of our work force. We also know that in the current economic circumstances, employers are looking for cost-effective ways in which to enhance the balance between work and family responsibilities and I know this is of great concern to my hon. friend.
A wide variety of practical strategies have been already implemented at little cost to reduce the stress associated with competing work and family priorities for workers, while at the same time meeting the employer's operational objectives.
The government is working toward ratification by Canada of the International Labour Organization Convention No. 156 on equal opportunities and equal treatment of workers with family responsibilities, hopefully to coincide with the celebration of the United Nations International Year of the Family in 1994.
The provinces are presently looking at the provisions of the convention. Taking this step would be an opportunity for Canada to communicate world-wide its commitment to meeting the needs of workers and family
May 19, 1992

responsibilities. I know my hon. friend who proposed this motion has been following this UN convention with interest.
The convention recognizes that change in the traditional role of men as well as women in society and in the family has to be recognized if there is to be full equality between men and women. It further states that the problems of workers with family responsibilities are aspects of wider issues regarding the family and society and are matters which should be taken into account in national policies.
Article 6 of the convention states that competent authorities in every country should take appropriate measures to promote information and education which engender broader public understanding of the principle of equality of opportunity and the treatment for men and women workers, including workers with family responsibilities.
I do not intend to go through the entire convention with hon. members, but there are provisions in this document which are important to the matter at hand. For instance, Article 9 recognizes that there are many important ways to achieve equal opportunities and treatment for workers with family responsibilities, be they men or women. These include, among others, collective agreements, work rules and appropriate practices.
We all should realize that the principal parties in any venture are best equipped to recognize their own requirements and then take the necessary steps to attain their goals. We know there is a growing sense of partnership between labour and management when it comes to the manner of work and family responsibilities.
We have heard about companies that have exercised initiative without recourse to legislation. This kind of action augers well for increasing collaboration between the stakeholders in this regard.
It is clear that Canada already has a progressive framework of legislation and practices in place with respect to the treatment and benefits accorded its workers. However, we in the government are determined to maintain our vigilance over matters related to labour standards and will amend and upgrade them as necessary in order to make them mirror the realities of the time.
Private Members' Business
As our employers and employees make adjustments to a restructured global economy and the increasingly competitive international marketplace, it is incumbent upon governments at all levels to respond if and when our existing regulations are inadequate.
The federal government will continue to monitor the whole world of work, but we will only step in with legal measures when it becomes absolutely necessary. In the meantime, it is prudent to allow market forces, coupled with a spirit of co-operation, to dictate the course of future arrangements in this very important area.
Under the circumstances I am sure hon. members will agree that the motion before us is certainly well-intended. As the hon. member from Winnipeg has indicated, he put this motion forward, I believe he said, back in 1989 for the first time. He indicated in committee that he might have approached it slightly differently and, as he mentioned in his speech, he would have included men as well as women in his redrafting. Certainly this bill is well-intended.
One of the members of the Conservative Party mentioned earlier that a new mother would have a lot of interest in the government taking heed, if not of passing the motion. Certainly it would be an indication to the government to take heed of this very important debate and this very important initiative that has been brought forward. Even though there are a number of non-legislative initiatives being implemented, they have to be implemented successfully and we have to see some results.
It is incumbent upon all of us to make these work and it is incumbent upon us to take special note of the motion put forward by our hon. friend from across the way and reflect upon it. As he has said, it is not legislation, it is proposed as a motion to have the government work toward legislation. If it does not reach that stage it certainly brings it to the attention of the House and all our constituents across the country who are listening that this is an important area of parental concern that we as a government and all members of the House should be concerned about, take heed of and watch as non-legislative approaches come forward. We hope that this will be successful and conclude in what the hon. member had in mind when he put forward this motion for the government to introduce legislation.

Routine Proceedings
I thank the hon. member for putting forward the motion and I thank the Speaker and the House for the opportunity to speak to it.

Mr. Speaker, on March 17, 1992,1 again raised in this House the issue of the Court Challenges Program, which as we know was abolished by the government in February. Many Canadians think this program is essential and I believe that it should be restored or reinstated. I asked the minister why, at a time when we are rethinking our constitutional future, the government abolished this program which is considered essential and as we know gave legal recourse to women, native people, racial minorities, linguistic and ethnic groups, who are very well aware that it is illusory to give them rights if these rights are not correctly interpreted by the courts. Why could the minister not give the cabinet convincing arguments so that all Canadians, whatever their means, rights and privileges, can defend themselves in court?
My party and I take this issue very seriously. April 1 was an opposition day and it was completely devoted to the Court Challenges Program. As you will recall, Mr. Speaker, I think that we proved beyond any doubt that the Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship and his colleagues who spoke in that debate did not have very strong or convincing arguments.
The body of precedents is far from complete, even though the minister said that there were 300 cases and that they now had a body of jurisprudence. He also told me that it was time for others-I will quote page 8362 of Hansard of March 17:
Whether a program must go on forever should be determined now either by other jurisdictions which have a responsibility, or by the private sector, if there is such an interest.
These causes were essential for Canadians to obtain a clear and precise interpretation of their rights regarding education and equality. I cannot imagine a more important issue, at a time of constitutional reform, than to give
Adjournment Debate
all Canadians, regardless of their revenue, the right to appear before a court.
The Conservative government has raised the issue of the cost of that program, which totals $2.7 million per year. This amount represents less than 10 cents per Canadian per year for a program that gave each and every one the possibility to go before the courts and defend their rights. This program was but a drop in the federal budget of some $160 billion.
I find it hard to see how the Conservative government was able to find $15 million to increase the budget of the legal services in the Department of Justice, that is $15 million for litigations, but could not find $2 million for the Court Challenges Program, which helped Canadians to protect their rights.
Numerous people wrote letters-I have received a great many and so has the government-including experts such as former judges from the Supreme Court, to say that this program was very useful. We also received many petitions. To this day, more than 5,500 petitioners have asked Parliament to restore this program.
This was not an expensive program but it was valuable. I will end with a quote from Mrs. Rolande Soucie, the vice-president of the Federation des communautes francophones et acadienne du Canada, and a former researcher here at the Library of Parliament. She said, regarding official languages: "The government sends a very ambiguous message. On the one hand, it is proud of the linguistic duality and it makes a big thing of it, especially at the international level, but it is not ready to support the individuals and groups that want to have their rights enshrined in the charter."
Once again I ask the government, on behalf of all the citizens that care about Canadian rights and liberties, to recognize its mistake and to restore as soon as possible the Court Challenges Program.

speakeroldname: Mr. Vincent Della Noce (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State and to Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship):

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have the dreadful task of answering to my hon. colleague who always puts his heart in what he does. As spokesperson for the government, I want to remind him that it is true that our nation is in the midst of constitutional debate-discussions that will indeed affect the future of Canada, but never the commitment to the basic rights and fundamental freedoms that our citizens share as Canadians.

May 19, 1992
Adjournment Debate
I am referring, of course, to a topic raised yet again; this government's decision to abolish federal funding of the Court Challenges Program. Our critics claim that, through this action, we are abandoning the 1982 Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. This is clearly not so. Rather, the charter remains a living document that will continue to be strengthened in our daily lives. However, in this period of fiscal restraint the government has to limit its expenditures.
The issues surrounding the equality and rights of disadvantaged and minority groups are shared by all of us. Canadians must do their part to join us in supporting our charter. This government is asking the leaders of the provinces, and of the private sector, to share the responsibility of enforcing our rights and freedoms within their own sphere of influence. Surely this is not too much to request of the very people who speak so strongly for those rights.
I reiterate for hon. members that we shall continue to pursue the fundamental values of Canadian citizenship that bear a direct impact on our daily lives: equality and participation.
In conclusion, the court challenges decision was a difficult one. We now ask our provincial colleagues and the private sector to work together with us in furthering our national human rights goals.

Mr. Speaker, when I rose in this House on April 28,1 asked the Prime Minister why his government has cut 40,000 jobs from the Summer Employment Experience Development program since 1985.
The minister of youth gave the expected response. He told the House the budget for the SEED program was increased last year and has been increased again this year. That is a very clever answer but it is misleading. Since 1985, this government has cut $72 million from SEED'S budgets. When one removes the $6 million that has been added over the past two years, there is a cumulative cut of $66 million. The government's increases are cosmetic and do not even begin to make up for the devastation caused by those earlier cuts.
The facts prove this. In 1990 when the total SEED budget was $77 million, the number of jobs created through SEED was 54,000. In 1991 with a budget increase of $3 million, the number of jobs created actually fell to 53,800. The reason for this drop is simple. While there are private companies and organizations in our communities that are willing to hire young people for the summer, they are unable to do so without the support of government. This government is robbing young people of the opportunity to work and is denying access to firms and organizations that are willing to tap into a dynamic and ambitious work force.
The statistics illustrate the cold hard truth. Without government help there will be no jobs for young people in this economy. While the general population struggles with an unemployment rate of 11 per cent, the rate for Canadians between the ages of 15 and 24 is 16.8 per cent. This is because young people are usually the first to be laid off in a recession and they are the last to be hired when the economy begins to recover.
For example, of the 32,000 full-time jobs that the Canadian economy lost in February 1992, 22,000 were held by young people. However, the worst effect of a youth unemployment rate of 16.8 per cent is that many young Canadians are being robbed of their future. I am speaking of those post-secondary education students who must work in order to pay their tuition fees, their living expenses and other costs. Because tuition fees have skyrocketed since 1985, it is critical for an increasing number of students to find work during the summer.
Between 1985 and 1991, tuition fees increased 45.5 per cent in Ontario and 145 per cent in the province of Quebec. If these students do not find work this summer, tens of thousands of them will be squeezed out of the system, unable to pay for their tuition or to support themselves. This happens at a time when the government is speaking about a prosperity agenda and global competitiveness, but the fact is I do not think that this government understands what it means to be competitive in a global market. Given the urgency of the situation, I call on the government to take action immediately. I call on it to increase its commitment to

the SEED program and create badly needed employment for Canada's youth.
Today is an extreme situation and it requires immediate measures. As a nation we cannot afford to have a generation of citizens who have given up on their future. We must not discard young Canadians who are badly in need of employment simply because they do not fit into rigid economic policies.
Anyone who doubts the urgency of this problem need look no further than this Sunday's Toronto Star edition which paints a very depressing portrait of the dire straits in which so many young Canadians now find themselves. I hope the government will understand that the future of these young people is a worth-while investment.

speakeroldname: Mr. Marcel R. Tremblay (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport) and Minister of State (Youth) and Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in response to a question asked by the hon. member for York North, I am pleased to discuss, on behalf of the Minister of State for Youth, the government's summer programming as it concerns Canada's youth.
This government is committed to assisting Canadian youth find employment. In this regard, a number of summer programs have been developed over the years to prepare Canadian youth for the challenges of the future. These programs are mostly funded under the Challenge '92 program whose allocation this year was set at $110 million.
The member is obviously interested in the SEED component of the challenge program which subsidizes summer jobs for Canadian students. The SEED (summer employment experience development) component of challenge '92 was increased by $3 million this summer to ensure that our commitment to youth was maintained. This means that this summer some 55,000 jobs will be created fo youth.
For the past two years, Ontario has distributed the SEED funds based on two factors: student population and communities experiencing unemployment rates greater than the provincial average. This concentrated funds in Northern Ontario, Windsor and the Niagara peninsula. This was and still is an acceptable way of doing business because it recognizes that other

Mr. Speaker, in late February of this year I raised a question in this House with the Minister of Employment and Immigration concerning the situation of two women living in the Yukon Territory, Andrea Underwood and Anna Carrott.
Andrea Underwood, a Canadian citizen, has been living with her partner Anna Carrott in a committed and loving relationship for some eight years together with Anna's children. This couple run a lodge in the Yukon, the Morley Lodge.
I asked the minister at that time to recognize the fundamental inhumanity of the policies of the immigration department which denied any status whatsoever to this and similar relationships. I urged the minister to extend Anna's visa while this case is being considered by the Federal Court.
I am very pleased that the minister did, in fact, agree to extend the visa in these circumstances. I want to take this opportunity to again draw to the attention of the House the fundamental cruelty and immorality of a policy which states that Canadians, men and women who are involved in committed loving relationships with non-Canadian citizens of the same sex, are denied any recognition whatsoever of those relationships in Canadian immigration law. In the eyes of the law that relationship does not exist. It is invisible.

May 19, 1992
Adjournment Debate
In a number of other countries including Australia, New Zealand, The Netherlands and Scandinavian countries, there are policies in place recognizing that same sex relationships should be recognized for purposes of immigration law.
Indeed, a task force of a number of individuals, a number of prominent citizens of British Columbia, chaired by Professor Douglas Sanders of the University of British Columbia, is looking into the whole question of the implications of the current discriminatory policies affecting the lesbian and gay community in Canada.
The government itself is studying these policies. It has been studying them for some three years. I received a letter from the Secretary of State for External Affairs back in 1989 in which she stated that she had asked her officials to look into the policies and consider the possibility on compassionate humanitarian grounds.
I have another letter from the current Minister of Employment and Immigration stating that this is being studied. But surely the time for study has ended. If the Charter of Rights and Freedoms is to mean anything, then there must be full equality.
On March 4, 1986 the federal government, this Conservative government announced that there would be an end to discrimination based on sexual orientation in all areas of federal jurisdiction. That must include immigration as well.
I want to pay tribute to the two women in the Yukon who have the courage to publicly challenge these policies, as well as to Christine Morrissey and her life companion of 14 years, Bridget Coll, who have challenged these policies similarly in the Federal Court.
As Ms. Morrissey said: "I feel as a Canadian I ought to have the same rights as any other Canadian to sponsor the person with whom I have chosen to share my life. We are not claiming any special rights for same sex couples but asking for the same consideration from the immigration department to be able to live in Canada with the life companion of our choice as any Canadian sponsoring a member of their family is given".
Christine Morrissey's 76-year old mother added: "I cannot understand why Christine is not allowed to sponsor Bridget for immigration".
I hope that the government will reconsider these policies. Unfortunately, the Court Challenges Program which was funding the challenge to this discriminatory area of the law has been eliminated. I hope that the funds will be there for Christine and Bridget and for the others who challenge these policies.
Again, I call upon the government to recognize there must be an end to discrimination in this area. It is time that this government recognized that lesbians and gay men are equal citizens in this country and entitled to be treated with equality, dignity and respect.

Mr. Speaker, on behalf of the Minister of Employment and Immigration, I welcome the opportunity to further discuss the matters raised by my hon. colleague, the member for Burnaby-Kingsway.
It is not possible to sponsor a same sex spouse under the Immigration Act. Such a relationship does not meet the current definition of spouse under the family class regulations. Given that this issue is now before the Federal Court, it would be inappropriate to use this House as a means to influence or interfere with this legal process.
I will take this opportunity, even if the member for Burnaby-Kingsway did not mention it earlier, to address another aspect of the question he submitted to the hon. Minister of Employment and Immigration on February 25 concerning the case of Mr. Abo Shandi. The Solicitor General and the minister signed a security certificate because of the seriousness of this case. I would also like to point out to the hon. member that the Federal Court found that this certificate was reasonable. This action to exclude terrorists and subversives from Canada clearly states this government's view that Canada will not be a safe haven for persons with active terrorist or subversive backgrounds who constitute a menace for Canada.

Mr. Speaker, on March 17 I asked the Secretary of State why in this year's budget the Canada 125 Corporation was allocated another $30 million, an outrageous 150 per cent funding increase, while many essential programs are being cut and cancelled.
Over the last two years, the Canada 125 Corporation has been allocated a total of $50 million of taxpayers' money. By contrast the Secretary of State has only $2 million for local community celebrations of Canada's 125th birthday.
Canadians will be astounded to know that this private non-profit corporation, whose three legal directors are Tories, is not subject to the same disclosure rules as government departments. Where is this government's accountability to the citizens of this country? Why would Canadians believe that the $50 million of public money is well managed when we hear of the waste and mismanagement by Canada 125 Corporation? A $1 million direct mail campaign brought only .001 per cent response. Also, $4.2 million was wasted on ambiguous TV ads which stirred up interest but gave no toll-free number for viewers to call. English pamphlets were distributed through direct mail when the French version could only be obtained by purchasing a newspaper. Over $71,000 went to two countries for the development of two different logos for the Canada 125 Corporation.
Is this efficient private sector management? Surely Secretary of State Department would have done it better and for a much lower cost.
The Canada 125 Corporation's mandate is to act as a catalyst for private sector initiatives, institutional projects and individual participation of Canadians from all walks of life. Yet none of the $50 million allocated to Canada 125 Corporation goes to direct funding for local community celebrations.
Local communities apply to the Department of Secretary of State which only has $2 million to fund about 1,700 projects for Canada. Remember this is half of the money wasted on TV ads. To celebrate this year, the demand has greatly increased while funds are the same through Secretary of State.
Adjournment Debate
In its last budget, this government abandoned Canadians who are most in need. The indefinite postponement of both the Canadian Race Relations Foundation and the Canadian Heritage Languages Institute, the abolishment of the Court Challenges Program, the elimination of co-op housing, a $100 million cut from job training programs, all these hurt the people who are most disadvantaged. Surely these programs are more important than pre-election pizzazz by corporate Canada.
We have a glorious country. Canada 125 celebrations are needed to lift our collective spirits and bring our country together. Canadians want our celebration to be fun and meaningful, involving people from all walks of life who come together to celebrate the joy of being Canadian and to celebrate our achievements and our common values.
Canadians want a government that is accountable and honest. Allocating $50 million of taxpayers' money for the Canada 125 Corporation with no public accountability, coupled with poor management, is a disgrace.
Instead of funding Canada 125 Corporation, this government should have increased funding through Secretary of State for community groups to hold genuine celebrations. Canadians deserve better.

speakeroldname: Mr. Vincent Della Noce (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State and to Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship; Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it gives me great pleasure to set the record straight about the partnership between the Government of Canada and the Canada 125 Corporation.
Last year, eminent and nationally recognized Canadians like Frank King, Iona Campagnolo -not Conservatives -Claude Dupras, Alex Colville, Mel Cooper, Paul Desmarais and Angus Reid came together in a spirit of public-mindedness to organize and coordinate a meaningful celebration of our great country's 125th anniversary.
The corporation has forged a strong and dynamic partnership across the breadth of Canada. Imperial Oil, Manu Life, Canadian Tire, Greyhound, Canada Dry and many others have joined with thousands of community volunteers to mount the celebration of our generation.

Adjournment Debate
For example, Participaction, with the kind sponsorship of Imperial Oil, has animated over 10,000 local events, making this anniversary a most special one.
The hon. member charges that this sum is a waste, but she should ask Montrealers how wonderful it was this weekend. I must say I was there. I would remind her that, in 1967, the Centennial Commission spent far more than this amount.
The philosophy of this government has been to build partnerships, not to impose solutions. Her party traditionally favours impositions and state intervention.
We on this side uphold what Canadians in 1989 resoundingly said-our celebration of Canada 125 must be a partnership and not a made-in-Ottawa event.
For far too long, Canadians have been somewhat reluctant to express their pride in Canada. Our approach to Canada 125 fosters the pride which is in each one of us.
For every four dollars spent by the Canadian gover-ment, the private and voluntary sectors are spending five.
On this side, we see this as a success. On their side, the hon. member's colleagues see any positive returns as a failure. What can we do.
